questions.text: Intramembranous ossification is seen in which bones?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maxilla

 

Option C)

 

INTRAMEMBRANOUS OSSIFICATION

 

  • When bone formation occurs directly in primitive connective tissue by proliferation, hypertrophy and transformation of cells into osteoblasts, progressive bone formation results in the fusion of adjacent bony areas within the membrane to form spongy bone.
  • It is seen in Skull vault, maxilla, majority of mandible and clavicle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pelvis and Option B. Long bones. These two bones have endochondral ossification where the bone formation occurs in the pre-existing cartilage formed from the mesenchymal tissues.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Maxilla is formed by intramembranous ossification while the pelvis and long bones are formed by endochondral ossification.

choices.text: Open wound with fracture with wound <1 cm
Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury
Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required
Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

questions.text: A patient with open wound with fracture of both bones of right lower limb came to the emergency. The doctor labelled the injury as 3B according to Gustilo-Anderson Classification. Which of the following would represent the injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

 

Option D)

 

OPEN FRACTURE CLASSIFICATION

 

  • Gustilo and Anderson classification is used for open fracture.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Open wound with fracture with wound < 1cm. This is type 1 of the Gustilo-Anderson classification where the wound is < 1cm in size and is a clear wound.

 

Option B. Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury. This is type 2 of the Gustilo-Anderson classification where the wound size is > 1cm without any extensive soft tissue damage, skin flap or avulsion.

 

Option C. Open wound > 10cm, though soft tissue coverage not required. This is the type 3A where there is adequate periosteal coverage present.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The type 3B of the open fracture involves significant periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone coverage procedure like skin grafting or flap.
  • The wound size is > 10cm in this type.

questions.text: The posterolateral lesion in the head of humerus in cases of recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hill-Sachs lesion

 

Option B)

 

HILL-SACHS LESION

 

  • A humeral head impaction fracture can be produced as the shoulder is dislocated anteriorly, and the humeral head is impacted against the rim of the glenoid at the time of dislocation.
  • This Hill-Sachs lesion is a defect in the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head.
  • If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair.
  • They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bankart’s lesion. In the Bankart’s lesion, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of tthe neck of the scapula. The Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

 

 

Option C. Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion. Reverse Hill-Sachs defect, also known as a McLaughlin lesion, is defined as an impaction fracture of anteromedial aspect of the humeral head following posterior dislocation of the humerus.

 

 

Option D. Greater tuberosity avulsion fracture. The greater tuberosity is the attachment site of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor tendons. Isolated fractures of the greater tuberosity are uncommon. Occasionally, a Hill–Sachs lesion in the humeral head may be confused with a fracture of the greater tuberosity.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The posterolateral lesion in the humeral head due to recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation is called as the Hill-Sachs lesion.

questions.text: Most vascular zone of the bone is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metaphysis

 

Option A)

 

METAPHYSIS

 

  • The metaphyses are the wide portions of long bones where growth occurs.
  • The metaphysis is located between the diaphysis and epiphysis.
  • A relatively rich blood supply and increased vascular stasis makes the metaphysis prone to hematogenous spread of infection and osteomyelitis.
  • There is hair-pin arrangement of vessels and there is more blood supply in this cancellous area of bone.

 

 

Blood vessels enter the bone through the nutrient foramen.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most vascular zone of the bone is the metaphysis.

questions.text: Increased Callus or Cartilage formation is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased mobilization

 

Option C)

 

CALLUS FORMATION

 

  • Although immobilization has to be provided to hold fracture ends in acceptable position; a micromotion increases callus formation which is not seen in 1o healing.
  • In bone healing and fracture repair, callus formation is the formation of a specialized tissue that bridges the gap between fractured bone ends, ultimately leading to the union of the bone.
  • Cartilage formation may also be part of this process, particularly in the early stages of bone healing.
  • Increased mobilization refers to allowing controlled movement or mechanical stimulation at the fracture site.
  • This can promote callus formation by stimulating bone growth and remodelling.
  • Controlled mobilization is often recommended during the later stages of bone healing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rigid immobilization. Rigid immobilization is the immobilization of the fractured bone using methods like casting or splinting to prevent movement. While immobilization is necessary for initial stabilization of the fracture, excessive rigidity may hinder callus formation and delay healing.

 

Option B. Necrosis of bone ends. Necrosis of bone ends is the death of bone tissue at the fracture site, which can occur due to severe injury or inadequate blood supply. Necrosis typically inhibits callus formation and delays healing.

 

Option D. Compression plating. Compression plating involves the use of metal plates and screws to stabilize fractured bones, applying compression across the fracture site. Compression plating can promote callus formation by providing mechanical stability and facilitating the alignment of bone fragments.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Controlled movement or mobilization at the fracture site can stimulate bone healing and promote the formation of callus tissue, aiding in the repair process.

choices.text: At the end of 2 months in intrauterine life

questions.text: The first centre of primary ossification appears at:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) At the end of 2 months in intrauterine life

 

Option A)

 

PRIMARY OSSIFICATION

 

  • Limbs appear at the end of 1st month of intrauterine life.
  • All long bones, with the exception of the clavicle, develop from cartilaginous primordia (endochondral ossification).
  • This type of ossification commences in the middle of the shaft (primary centre of ossification) before birth, usually beginning by the end of 2nd month of intrauterine life.
  • Muscles and joints appear in 3rd month.
  • The secondary ossification centres (the epiphyses) appear at the ends of the bone, mostly around and after birth.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. End of 3rd month. While ossification continues throughout the fetal development and in the post-natal life, the initiation of ossification usually occurs earlier, around the beginning of the third month, rather than at the end.

 

Option D. End of 4th month. This timeline is later than when ossification typically begins. By the end of the fourth month, multiple centres of ossification may have already appeared in various bones, but the process usually starts earlier, around the beginning of the third month.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The first centre of primary ossification appears at the end of 2nd month of the intrauterine life.

questions.text: Marker for bone formation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteocalcin

 

Option B)

 

OSTEOCALCIN

 

  • During bone growth and development, bone formation, i.e. osteoblastic activity predominates.
  • Osteocalcin is used as sensitive and specific serum marker for osteoblastic activity.
  • Osteoblast cells are responsible for the synthesis of major protein of bone including type I collagen and non-collagen proteins such as osteocalcin (bone Gla protein) and osteonectin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tartate resistant acid phosphatase. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is an iron-containing enzyme. It is present in bone and cartilage. TRAP is highly expressed in chondroclasts and osteoclasts and, therefore, is used as a specific histochemical marker for these cells. TRAP prompts dephosphorylation of bone matrix phosphoproteins like osteopontin and bone sialoprotein and is important for a normal endochondral bone formation. TRAP deficiency leads to a reduced resorptive activity during endochondral ossification resulting in an osteopetrotic phenotype and shortened long bones.

 

Option C. Urinary calcium. Urinary calcium does not correlate with the bone formation or resorption markers as it can provide information about calcium metabolism and bone health but cannot be used as a specific marker.

 

Option D. Serum nucleotidase. Serum nucleotidase is an enzyme that hydrolyzes nucleotides in the blood serum. It is not directly involved in bone metabolism or specifically associated with bone formation. Serum levels of nucleotidase are strongly correlated with serum alkaline phosphatase levels and have relative specificity for liver disease.

 

Educational objective:

 

MARKERS FOR BONE FORMATION

 

  1. Serum bone specific alkaline phosphatase
  2. Serum osteocalcin (very important marker)
  3. Serum peptide of type I procollagen
  4. Type 1 collagen extension peptide (product of type I collagen degradation – more specific)
  • Osteocalcin or bone Gla protein (BGP) is raised in diseases with increased bone turnover, e.g. Paget's disease, renal osteodystrophy and primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

MARKERS OF BONE RESORPTION

 

  1. Urine and serum cross linked N telopeptide
  2. Urine and serum cross linked C telopeptide
  3. Urine total free deoxypyridinoline
  4. Urine hydroxyproline (very important marker)
  5. Urine hydroxylysine glycosides
  6. Serum tartrate resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP)
  7. Serum bone sialoprotein

 

Thus, among the given options, Osteocalcin is used as a marker for bone formation as it is produced by the osteoblast cells. Its presence in the blood stream indicated active bone formation.

choices.text: Osteoclastic activity at the compression site
Osteoclastic activity at the tension site
Osteoclastic activity and osteoblastic activity are both needed for bone remodelling in cortical and cancellous bones

questions.text: Regarding bone remodelling, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoclastic activity at the compression site

 

Option A:

 

BONE REMODELLING

 

  • Bone remodeling is a continuous, lifelong process where mature bone tissue is removed from the skeleton (bone resorption by osteoclasts) and new bone tissue is formed (bone formation by osteoblasts). 
  • This process allows the skeleton to adapt to mechanical stresses, repair micro-damage, and maintain mineral homeostasis.
  • Bone remodelling has both osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity at compression or tension side but the forces on bone decide where remodelling takes place â€“ compressible forces at compression site and tensile forces at tension site and in bone modelling, there is osteoclastic activity at tension site and osteoblastic activity at compression site. 
  • Wolff's Law states that bone in a healthy person or animal will adapt to the loads under which it is placed. If loading increases, the bone will remodel itself over time to become stronger to resist that loading. If loading decreases, the bone will become weaker.
  • In areas of compression, bone needs to be strong to withstand the forces. According to Wolff's Law and the principles of bone adaptation, there would typically be more osteoblastic activity at sites experiencing significant compression to increase bone density and strength. Excessive osteoclastic activity at a compression site would weaken the bone where strength is needed, which is contrary to the adaptive nature of remodelling.
  • Therefore, this statement â€œOsteoclastic activity at the compression siteâ€ is likely false.

 

 

Overall osteoclastic activity at tension surface and osteoblastic activity at compression surface

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteoclastic activity at the tension site. True. In bone remodeling, there is osteoclastic activity at the tension site. Osteoclasts help in reshaping the bone in response to mechanical forces. In contrast to compression, sites under tension (pulling forces) often experience bone resorption. For example, in bone growth and remodeling, bone might be resorbed on one side of a bone to allow for appositional growth on the other side, or to reshape bone in response to tensile forces. This is a normal part of how bone adapts and reshapes.

 

Option C. Osteoclastic activity and osteoblastic activity are both needed for bone remodelling in cortical and cancellous bones. True. Bone remodeling involves a balance between bone resorption by osteoclasts and bone formation by osteoblasts. Both activities are essential for maintaining bone strength and structure, regardless of whether the bone is cortical or cancellous. Osteoclasts resorb old bone, creating cavities, and then osteoblasts fill these cavities with new bone. 

 

Option D. Osteoblasts transform into osteocytes. True. Osteoblasts are bone-forming cells responsible for synthesizing new bone tissue. As they become embedded in the bone matrix they produce, they differentiate into osteocytes, which are mature bone cells, and play crucial roles in bone maintenance, mechanosensation, and signaling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In areas of compression, bone typically responds by increasing its density and strength through osteoblastic activity (bone formation), not by being resorbed by osteoclasts.
  • Thus, the best answer here will be Option A) but this is with respect to modelling not remodelling.

choices.text: Abnormal mobility at fracture site
Pain at the fracture site

questions.text: Diagnostic sign of a fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abnormal mobility at fracture site

 

Option A)

 

CLINICAL FEATURES OF FRACTURE

 

  • Tenderness is the commonest (consistent) sign of fracture.
  • Abnormal mobility and loss of transmitted movements is surest sign of fracture.
  • Crepitus occurs because of rubbing of both fracture ends together and gives sense of friction between fractured ends; it should not be elicited as it may cause neurogenic shock or may cause comminution at fracture ends due to rubbing of bone ends.
  • Crepitus may also be positive in bursitis or subcutaneous emphysema.
  • Thus crepitus is not a very reliable sign of fracture as the above two, but if abnormal mobility and loss of transmitted movements are not mentioned than crepitus has to be chosen as the answer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pain at the fracture site, Option C. Tenderness, and Option D. Swelling all are present at the site of fracture but are not always the diagnostic signs of fracture. Tenderness is the most consistent sign of fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • All the given options are the signs of fracture but the most diagnostic is the abnormal movement or loss of movement at the site of fracture while the most consistent sign is the tenderness.

questions.text: A patient with gunshot wound in tibia presents with comminuted fracture tibia with 2 cm wound. This belongs to what grade of Gustilo-Anderson classification of open fractures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Grade II 

 

Option B)

 

OPEN FRACTURE CLASSIFICATION

 

  • The Gustilo-Anderson classification system categorizes open fractures based on the severity of soft-tissue damage and wound size.

 

 

  • In the given scenario, a 2 cm wound indicates Grade II. 
  • While the fracture is comminuted, the size and extent of soft-tissue damage falls within the criteria for Grade II.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Grade I. Grade I open fractures involve a clean wound less than 1 cm in size with minimal soft tissue damage. These fractures typically have a low risk of infection.

 

Option C. Grade IIIA: This grade involves more severe soft-tissue damage or a segmental fracture, which is not described in the question.

 

Option D. Grade IIIB. Grade IIIB open fractures also involve significant soft tissue damage, but in addition, they have extensive periosteal stripping, vascular injury requiring repair, or contaminated wounds. These fractures typically require soft tissue coverage procedures like flap reconstruction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given type of injury in the question is comminuted fracture of the tibia but the size and extent of the soft tissue damage falls within the criteria of Grade II injury. 
  • So, the described comminuted fracture in this patient will be classified under grade II of the Gustilo-Anderson classification of open fracture.

questions.text: Internal Fixation is primarily used in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Compound fractures

 

Option A)

 

TYPE AND METHOD OF FIXATION OF OPEN FRACTURE

 

 

Note: Remember usual treatment for open fractures is debridement (more important) and external fixator.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Multiple fractures. Internal fixation is often employed in cases of multiple fractures to realign and stabilize the fractured bones, facilitating the healing process.

 

Option C. Fractures in elderly patient. Fractures in elderly patients, especially those resulting from osteoporosis or low bone density, may require internal fixation to stabilize the fractured bones and aid in the healing process. In fact, due to the decreased bone density and healing capacity in elderly individuals, internal fixation may be particularly important in these cases.

 

Option D. Fracture neck of femur. The fracture neck of the femur is a common injury, especially in elderly individuals. Internal fixation is often the primary treatment approach for fractures of the femoral neck, as it helps stabilize the fractured bone and allows for early mobilization, reducing the risk of complications such as avascular necrosis or non-union.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The mainstay of treatment of compound/open fractures is the surgical debridement and external fixation.
  • Internal fixation is done usually in grade I of the open fractures and in the closed fractures.

choices.text: Risk of pathological fracture after metastasis

questions.text: Mirel’s criteria is developed for the evaluation of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risk of pathological fracture after metastasis

 

Option C)

 

MIREL’S CRITERIA FOR RISK OF PATHOLOGICAL FRACTURE

 

  • Mirel's developed a scoring system based on, the presence or absence of pain, and the size, location, and radiographic appearance of the lesion to quantify the risk of impending pathological fracture in malignant lesion.

 

 

  • So, patients with maximum risk of pathological fracture are having lytic peri-trochanteric lesion involving > 2/3rd diameter with severe pain.
  • Patients with < 7 score are observed, but those with score > 8 should have prophylactic internal fixation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Risk of fatigue fracture. Fatigue fractures, also known as stress fractures, occur due to repetitive stress or overuse of bones, leading to microscopic cracks in the bone. Evaluating the risk of fatigue fracture involves assessing various factors related to the individual and the activities they engage in. These factors include high impact activities, poor training techniques, anatomical variations (LLDs, foot arch abnormality, abnormal gait pattern), low bone density, inadequate nutrition, previous history of stress fracture, adolescents, female athletes, long term use of corticosteroids.

 

Option B. Severity of osteoporosis. This is evaluated on the basis of the T-score in the dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan.

 

 

Option D. Severity of neurological deficit. The severity of neurological deficits refers to the extent of impairment or dysfunction of the nervous system, which can vary widely depending on the underlying cause and the specific nerves or regions of the nervous system affected. Evaluating the severity of neurological deficits involves assessing various clinical parameters and objective findings. Various criteria used are Modified Ashworth Scale to evaluate motor function, sensory function testing using various stimuli, deep tendon reflexes, coordination and balance testing, gait observation, vital sign monitoring, neurophysiological testing, imaging and electrophysiological studies.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Mirel’s criteria is used to evaluate the risk of pathological fracture after metastasis on the basis of presence of pain, and size, location and radiographic appearance of the lesion.

questions.text:
Following are immediate complications of fracture:

 

  1. Vascular ischemia
  2. Neuronal injury
  3. Malunion
  4. Compartment syndrome
  5. Avascular necrosis
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) 1, 2

 

Option A)

 

 

Explanation:

 

3. Malunion. Malunion is the delayed complication of fracture.

 

4. Compartment syndrome. It is the early complication of the fracture.

 

5. Avascular necrosis. It is the delayed complication of fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Vascular ischemia and neuronal injury are the immediate complications of the fracture.

choices.text: Roll the patient making sure there is no movement of the spine on to a hard board
Strap the patient’s head, thorax & pelvis to a flat hard board in supine position
Turn the patient to one side
Assess the patient by asking his name

questions.text: While attending to a victim of RTA, who is otherwise conscious, all the following can be done except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Turn the patient to one side

 

Option C)

 

RESUSCITATION PROTOCOL

 

  • All resuscitations of a poly traumatized patient should be performed using Advanced trauma life support (ATLS) guidelines.
  • Assessment of the patient is performed using a stepwise longitudinal approach.
  • Spine must be immobilized appropriately before starting the resuscitation protocol.
  • Primary survey:
    • Airway (with cervical spine protection first), Breathing and Circulation are assessed.
    • The goal is to immediately provide the patent airway while maintaining a manual in line stabilization of spinal cord.
  • Airway:
    • Ask the patient any question, e.g. Ask his name, ask how he/she is feeling.
    • If the patient responds verbally, it means he/she has an intact airway, is breathing, is thinking.
    • Also the patient’s level of consciousness can be briefly assessed (option D is correct).
    • If the patient is unresponsive, check airway patency by looking at patient’s chest.
    • Look for chest expansion, listen and feel for air movement.
    • If doubtful, airway patency can be maintained using jaw thrust (head tilt/chin lift maneuver only if cervical spine injury has been ruled out).
    • Because the most common cause of airway obstruction is base of tongue falling backward into the posterior pharynx.
    • Jaw thrust will uplift the tongue and relieve the obstruction.
    • Definitive Airway management achieves 3 Ps: Airway patency, aspiration protection and positive pressure ventilation.
    • Intubation is the criterion standard of airway management: Orotracheal/Nasotracheal intubation.
    • Surgical airway: Circothyrodotomy is usually a last resort when intubation is unsuccessful.
    • The spine should be protected immediately at all times during the management of the multiply injured patient.
    • This may be achieved manually (Manual in line stabilization) or with a combination of semi-rigid cervical collar, side head supports for head immobilization and strapping and using a spine board.
    • Strapping for stabilization should be applied to the shoulders/Thorax and pelvis as well as the Head to prevent the neck becoming the centre of rotation of the body (option B is correct).
    • The ideal position is with the spine immobilized in a neutral position on a firm surface/hard board.
    • If the neck is not in the neutral position, proper immobilization is achieved with the patient in neutral position, such that no rotation/bending of spinal column should be allowed.
    • If the patient is awake and conscious/cooperative/neurologically normal, as mentioned in the question, they should actively move their neck into line, because these are unlikely to have acute cervical spine injury.
    • If unconscious, this is done passively.
    • Patient should be LOG ROLLED, when moving to and fro from the hard board.
    • The Four-person log roll is the standard maneuver to allow examination of the back and transfer on and off back boards.
    • Neutral anatomic alignment of the entire vertebral column must be maintained while rolling and lifting the patient. (option A is correct).
    • Hence, option C becomes an incorrect choice.
    • Considering, the patient can be a suspected spine injury, patient hence should be least mobilized.
  • Imaging:
    • When available, all such patients should undergo Multidetector axial CT.
    • CT is the most sensitive imaging modality to evaluate spine injury/fractures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Roll the patient making sure there is no movement of the spine on to a hard board. True. Neutral anatomical alignment of the entire vertebral column must be maintained while rolling on to the hard board. 4-person log roll maneuver must be used to examine the back and transfer the patient.

 

Option B. Strap the patient’s head, thorax and pelvis to a flat hard board in supine position. True. Strapping of the shoulder, thorax and pelvis, and the head must be done to stabilize the structures and prevent the neck to become the center of rotation of the body.

 

Option D. Assess the patient by asking his name. True. On asking the questions, if the patient responds verbally, it means that the airway is intact and the patient is breathing and thinking. This can also assess the level of consciousness of the patient.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Turning the patient to one side will be an incorrect maneuver as this can lead to spinal injuries.
  • The victim of RTA, conscious/unconscious, must be least mobilized, and must be moved after properly stabilizing the spine.

choices.text: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, treatment of extracranial injuries
Treatment of extracranial injuries, Airway, Breathing, Circulation
Circulation, Airway, Breathing, treatment of extracranial injuries
Airway, circulation, breathing, treatment of extracranial injuries

questions.text: The correct order of priorities in the initial management of road traffic accident patient is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Airway, Breathing, Circulation, treatment of extracranial injuries

 

Option A)

 

PRIMARY SURVEY (ABCDEF)

 

  1. Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection:
  1. The finding of non-purposeful motor responses strongly suggests the need for definitive airway management.
  2. Assume a cervical spine injury in any patient with multisystem trauma, especially those with altered level of consciousness or blunt injury above the clavicle.
  3. Open the airway by Chin lift or Jaw thrust manoeuvre.
  1. Breathing and ventilation:
  • Tension pneumothorax, flail chest with pulmonary contusion, massive haemothorax and open pneumothorax must be detected in primary survey.
  1. Circulation with hemorrhage control:
  • Major areas of occult blood loss are the chest, abdomen, retroperitoneum, pelvis and long bones. They should be carefully handled.
  1. Disability: Neurological status (GCS especially the best motor response)
  2. Exposure/Environmental control: Prevent Hypothermia
  3. Fracture splintage – Rule of splintage: The joints above and below the fracture should be immobilized.
  • Consider need for patient transfer.
  • Secondary survey (head to toe evaluation and patient history): only after vital functions are normalized.
  • Continued post-resuscitation monitoring and re-evaluation.
  • Definitive care

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The correct order of priorities in the initial management of road traffic accident patient is Airway, Breathing, Circulation, and Disability (treatment of extracranial injuries).

questions.text: Shoulder flexion is done by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pectoralis major

 

Option B)

 

SHOULDER MUSCLES AND THEIR FUNCTION

 

  • Pectoralis major is an internal rotator and forward flexor of shoulder.
  • It also causes horizontal adduction.
  • Principle muscles acting on shoulder are:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posterior fibres of deltoid. The posterior fibres of deltoid muscle are the primary external rotators of the shoulder along with infraspinatus and teres minor.

 

Option C. Pectoralis minor. The primary actions of this muscle include the stabilization, depression, abduction or protraction, internal rotation and downward rotation of the scapula.

 

Option D. Latissimus dorsi. This muscle helps in the extension, adduction and internal rotation of the shoulder.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Shoulder flexion is done mainly by the clavicular part of the pectoralis major muscle along with the anterior fibres of the deltoid muscle.

questions.text: Bankart’s lesion is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation

 

Option A)

 

LESIONS ASSOCIATED WITH RECURRENT DISLOCATION

 

  • In 1938, Bankart published his classic paper in which he recognized two types of acute dislocations.
  • In the first type, the humeral head is forced through the capsule where it is the weakest, generally anteriorly and inferiorly in the interval between the lower border of the subscapularis and the long head of the triceps muscle.
  • In the second type, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears not only the fibrocartilaginous labrum (almost the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity), but also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula.
  • This traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum has been called the Bankart lesion.
  • Most authors agree that the Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

 

 

Bankart’s lesion

 

  • A humeral head impaction fracture can be produced as the shoulder is dislocated anteriorly, and the humeral head is impacted against the rim of the glenoid at the time of dislocation.
  • This Hill-Sachs lesion is a defect in the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head.
  • If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair.
  • They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Hill-Sachs lesion

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Posterior shoulder dislocation. These are associated with Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion. There is an impaction fracture of the anteromedial aspect of the humeral head following the posterior dislocation. The radiographs shows loss of normal convexity and presence of a wedge defect in the anteromedial aspect of the humeral head.

 

 

Option C. Rotator cuff tear. Rotator cuff injuries are associated with instability of the shoulder. Bankart’s lesion is specifically associated with anterior shoulder instability.

 

Option D. Inferior shoulder dislocation. Bankart's lesion is not typically associated with inferior shoulder dislocation because the injury to the labrum occurs in the anterior portion of the shoulder joint, whereas inferior dislocations involve displacement of the humeral head in a different direction, usually downwards.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Bankart’s lesion or the traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum is a pathological lesion in the recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

questions.text: What is the normal orientation of humeral head?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retroversion of 30 degrees

 

Option B)

 

HUMERAL HEAD POSITION

 

  • The normal orientation of the humeral head refers to its natural position within the shoulder joint.

  • This orientation is important for proper function and stability of the shoulder.

  • Normal orientation of the humeral head is Retroversion (i.e., rotated backward relative to the distal humerus)
    • Average value: 30 degrees (can range between 20â€“40 degrees in different individuals)
  • Retroverted position allows proper articulation of the humeral head with the glenoid fossa of the scapula.
  • It aligns the humeral head to optimize shoulder range of motion, particularly in overhead and external rotation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Retroversion of 80 degrees. 80 degrees of retroversion would be an excessive amount and is not within the normal range.

 

Option C. Anteversion of 15 degrees. Would cause anterior instability and is abnormal.

 

Option D. Anteversion of 50 degrees. This option suggests a significantly greater amount of anteversion, with the humeral head being anteverted by 50 degrees. It is anatomically incorrect for the humeral head (some femoral heads have anteversion, but not humeral).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal orientation of the humeral head is retroversion of 30Â°.

questions.text: Which of the following structure passes through the quadrangular space?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axillary nerve

 

Option A)

 

QUADRANGULAR SPACE

 

  • The quadrangular space is a rectangular-shaped anatomical space in the posterior axillary region.
  • It provides a conduit for structures to pass between the axilla and the posterior compartment of the arm.
  • Borders:
    • Superior – inferior margin of teres minor
    • Lateral – surgical neck of the humerus
    • Medial – long head of triceps brachii
    • Inferior – superior aspect of teres major

 

 

  • Contents:
    • The quadrangular space is a passage-way that allows structures to travel between the axilla and posterior compartment of the upper arm.
    • The Quadrangular space (Quadrilateral space, foramen of Velpeau) contains axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery and vein.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Radial nerve. The radial nerve exits the axilla posterior to the brachial artery and then enters the posterior arm compartment through the triangular interval. The triangular interval is bounded by the triceps brachii's long head medially, the teres major superiorly, and the humerus laterally.

 

Option C. Median nerve. The median nerve enters the anterior compartment of the forearm via the cubital fossa. In the forearm, the nerve travels between the two heads of pronator teres, and then descends in a plane between the flexor digitorum profundus and flexor digitorum superficialis muscles.

 

Option D. Brachial artery. The brachial artery courses along the ventral surface of the arm and gives rise to multiple smaller branching arteries before reaching the cubital fossa.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Quadrangular space is a passage-way in the posterior axillary region that allows the passage of the axillary nerve and the posterior circumflex humeral vessels.

questions.text: Bankart’s lesion involves the ____ of the glenoid labrum.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anter-inferior lip

 

Option D)

 

BANKART’S LESION

 

  • The glenoid labrum is a fibrocartilaginous ring attached circumferentially to the glenoid rim contributing to the stability of the shoulder joint.
  • The glenoid labrum increases the glenoid surface vertically by 75% and horizontally by 57%.
  • Bankart's lesion represents an anterior and inferior labral detachment from the glenoid with an associated capsuloligamentous injury below the equator of the glenoid. 
  • This result in anterior instability of the shoulder joint due to the loss of the normal mechanisms, such as the choke block effect of the labrum, concavity compression mechanism of the rotator cuff, and function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament. 
  • Traumatic subluxations or dislocations of the shoulder joint cause injury to the glenoid labrum.
  • Almost 87-100% of anterior shoulder dislocations are associated with Bankart lesions.
  • The soft tissue Bankart lesion is an injury to the anteroinferior glenoid labrum and capsule-ligament complex.
  • It is a pure soft-tissue injury. 
  • Bankart lesion is caused explicitly by anterior shoulder dislocation with the shoulder in external rotation and abduction.

 

 

Bankart lesion

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Superior lip. Lesion of the superior lip of the glenoid labrum is called SLAP lesion.

 

Option C. Antero-superior lip. While Bankart's lesion primarily affects the anterior portion of the labrum, the term "antero-superior" is not commonly used to describe the location of the injury. Bankart's lesions are generally described in relation to the anterior aspect of the labrum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bankart’s lesion involves injury to the antero-inferior lip of the glenoid labrum.

questions.text: Avulsion of capsulolabral complex is seen from which part of glenoid in bankart’s lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anteroinferior

 

Option A)

 

BANKART’S LESION

 

  • Bankart's lesion refers to an injury to the labrum and associated structures in the shoulder joint, usually occurring as a result of traumatic anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • In Bankart's lesion, the avulsion of the capsulolabral complex typically occurs from the anteroinferior part of the glenoid.
  • The anterior portion of the labrum and the surrounding capsule are often detached from this area due to the forceful displacement of the humeral head during anterior shoulder dislocation.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Posteroinferior: Bankart's lesion primarily affects the anterior portion of the shoulder joint rather than the posterior portion. Avulsion of the capsulolabral complex from the posteroinferior part of the glenoid is characteristic of reverse Bankart's lesion.

 

Option C. Anterosuperior: Bankart's lesion primarily involves the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid rather than the anterosuperior aspect. While injuries can occur in various locations around the glenoid, Bankart's lesions are specifically associated with avulsion from the anteroinferior area.

 

Option D. Posterosuperior: Avulsion from the posterosuperior part of the glenoid is typical of SLAP lesions.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Avulsion of the capsulolabral complex of the glenoid in Bankart’s lesion occurs from the anteroinferior or anterior lip of the labrum.

questions.text: Dynamic stabilisers of shoulder joint is/are:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotator cuff muscles

 

Option B)

 

DYNAMIC SHOULDER STABILIZERS

 

  • Four rotator cuff muscles—supraspinatus, infraspinatus, subscapularis and teres minor are the dynamic stabilisers of shoulder.
  • Their impingement causes painful arc syndrome.

 

 

  • The tendon of rotator cuff muscles blend with the joint capsule and form a musculotendinous collar that surrounds the posterior, superior, and anterior aspect of gleno-humeral joint.
  • The inferior part of shoulder joint capsule is the weakest area.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glenoid labrum, Option C. Glenohumeral ligament and Option D. Coracohumeral ligament are the static stabilizers of the shoulder.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Rotator cuff muscles along with the periscapular muscles are the dynamic stabilizers of the shoulder joint.

questions.text: For long, this muscle was not given its due importance and was called “Forgotten muscle of rotator cuff”. Which one is it?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subscapularis

 

Option A)

 

SUBSCAPULARIS

 

  • For years, shoulder surgeons were aware of the very common supraspinatus tears.
  • On the contrary, tears of the subscapularis commonly involve only a portion of the tendon, and they sometimes start deep in the joint, where without the benefit of looking at the tendon from the inside (as done in arthroscopic surgery), they are difficult to identify.
  • When subscapularis tears are missed at the time of surgical repair of the rotator cuff, the shoulder is seldomly perfect after recovery.
  • In fact, many times it hurts a lot and it feels weak.
  • Over the last few years, shoulder experts have become more aware of these tears, and techniques have been developed to find subscapularis tears at the time of arthroscopic surgery.
  • Subscapularis tears are hidden and forgotten no more! 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The subscapularis muscle is the largest and strongest muscle of the rotator cuff.
  • It originates from the subscapular fossa of the scapula and inserts onto the lesser tubercle of the humerus.
  • Its primary function is to internally rotate the arm at the shoulder joint and to assist in stabilizing the humeral head within the glenoid cavity.
  • Despite its importance, the subscapularis muscle has historically received less attention compared to the other rotator cuff muscles, leading to its designation as the "Forgotten muscle of the rotator cuff."

questions.text: Most common muscle damaged in rotator cuff is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraspinatus

 

Option A)

 

ROTATOR CUFF MUSCLE

 

  • Located on the top of the shoulder, supraspinatus is the most commonly injured tendon in the rotator cuff.
  • Supraspinatus is commonly injured due to the following reasons:
    • Anatomical Location: The supraspinatus muscle is situated at the top of the shoulder joint and passes beneath the acromion, forming the roof of the subacromial space. This location makes it particularly vulnerable to impingement between the humeral head and the acromion during certain arm movements, leading to irritation, inflammation, and eventually, injury.
    • Role in Shoulder Function: The supraspinatus muscle plays a crucial role in initiating abduction of the shoulder joint. It is the first muscle activated during this movement, especially during the first 15 to 30 degrees of abduction. This frequent activation makes it prone to overuse injuries, particularly in activities that involve repetitive overhead motions, such as throwing, swimming, or lifting weights.
    • Vascular Supply: The blood supply to the supraspinatus tendon is relatively poor, particularly in its critical zone where it attaches to the greater tuberosity of the humerus. This area is prone to degeneration and tearing, especially with repetitive stress or trauma.
    • Age-Related Changes: With aging, degenerative changes can occur within the tendon of the supraspinatus muscle, making it more susceptible to injury. These changes can include tendon degeneration, decreased vascularity, and alterations in the composition of the tendon matrix, all of which weaken the tendon and increase the risk of tears.
    • Repetitive Overhead Activities: Many sports and occupations involve repetitive overhead movements, which can place excessive stress on the supraspinatus tendon. Over time, this repetitive stress can lead to microtrauma, tendonitis, and eventually, partial or complete tears of the tendon.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Infraspinatus, Option C. Subscapularis muscles are not commonly injured because of their anatomical position (anterior and posterior position shield them from direct trauma/impingement), their more involvement in rotational movements and shoulder stabilization rather than initiating abduction, their adequate blood supply, and larger strength.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly injured muscle among the rotator cuff muscles is the supraspinatus muscled due to its anatomical location at the top of the shoulder joint, capability of being prone to overuse injury and degeneration, and poor blood supply.

questions.text: Rotator cuff muscle all are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Teres major

 

Option D)

 

ROTATOR CUFF MUSCLES

 

  • Four rotator cuff muscles are:
    • supraspinatus
    • infraspinatus
    • subscapularis
    • teres minor
  • They are dynamic stabilisers of shoulder.
  • Their impingement causes painful arc syndrome.

 

 

 

  • The tendon of rotator cuff muscles blend with the joint capsule and form a musculotendinous collar that surrounds the posterior, superior, and anterior aspect of gleno-humeral joint.
  • The inferior part of shoulder joint capsule is the weakest area.

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Teres major. The teres major is a thick muscle of the shoulder joint. It spans from the inferior aspect of the scapula to the proximal part of the humeral shaft. Unlike the teres minor, the teres major muscle does not attach to the capsule of the glenohumeral joint. Thus, it is not regarded as part of the rotator cuff muscles.

 

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The SITS muscles of the rotator cuff blends with the shoulder joint capsule.
  • Teres major muscle do not attach to the shoulder joint capsule, thus it does not form the part of the rotator cuff.
  • Therefore, the rotator cuff muscles are Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Teres minor and Subscapularis; and does not include Teres major.

questions.text: Lift off test is done for:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subscapularis

 

Option D)

 

LIFT OFF TEST (GERBER’S TEST)

 

  • Lift off test is done to assess the strength of subscapularis muscle and detect a rupture of the subscapularis tendon.
  • Subscapularis functions primarily as an internal rotator of the shoulder.
  • The test is performed with the arm extended and internally rotated such that the dorsum of the hand rests against the lower back. Subscapularis is maximally active in this position.
  • Patient is then instructed to lift his/her hand off the back (Lift-off) (Attempting further internal rotation).
  • If the patient is able to lift the dorsum of the hand off the back, the subscapularis tendon is intact and the test is considered negative.
  • If the patient is not able to lift the dorsum of the hand off the back, the subscapularis tendon is torn and the test is considered positive.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Supraspinatus. Empty Can Test is done for Supraspinatus muscle and tendon lesion. The patient's arm is elevated to 90 degrees in the scapular plane, with the elbow extended, full internal rotation, and pronation of the forearm. This results in a thumbs-down position. The therapist stabilizes the shoulder while applying a downward force to the arm, the patient tries to resist this motion. This test is considered positive if the patient experiences pain or weakness with resistance.

 

 

Option B. Infraspinatus and Option C. Teres minor. The patient is asked to externally rotate the shoulder with the arm by the side of the body. The examiner applies resistance to the movement. This produces pain at the greater tuberosity, at the site of the tendinitis.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lift off test is done for the testing of the subscapularis muscle/tendon lesions.

questions.text: Muscle crossing through the shoulder joint is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biceps long head

 

Option B)

 

  • Long head of biceps goes through the shoulder joint.
  • It originates from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula and inserts into the radius.
  • Thus, it crosses both the shoulder as well as the elbow joints.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Biceps short head. The short head originates from the apex of the coracoid process of the scapula and inserts into the radius. Thus, it crosses only the elbow joint.

 

Option C. Triceps long head. It originates from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula and inserts into the olecranon process of the ulna. Thus, it also crosses only the elbow joint.

 

Option D. Corachobrachialis. It is a small muscle that originates from the coracoid process of the scapula and inserts into the humerus. It does not cross the shoulder joint.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Out of the given options, only the long head of the biceps brachii crosses the shoulder joint.

questions.text: Weakest portion of shoulder joint capsule is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior

 

Option C)

 

SHOULDER JOINT CAPSULE

 

  • Shoulder is weakest inferiorly but dislocates anteriorly because it is the direction of force that decides the dislocation but never the anatomical weakness for a particular joint, e.g. the force that causes anterior dislocation (Abduction and external rotation) is much more common as in throwing objects like ball or javelin as compared to force that causes inferior dislocation.
  • The tendon of rotator cuff muscles blend with the joint capsule and form a musculotendinous collar that surrounds the posterior, superior, and anterior aspect of gleno-humeral joint.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The shoulder joint capsule is weakest in its inferior region because inferiorly, there is no musculotendinous cover around the capsule.

choices.text: Rupture of tendon of supraspinatus muscle

questions.text: Hill-Sachs lesion in recurrent shoulder dislocation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Injury to humeral head

 

Option A)

 

HILL- SACHS LESION

 

  • A humeral head impaction fracture can be produced as the shoulder is dislocated anteriorly, and the humeral head is impacted against the rim of the glenoid at the time of dislocation.
  • This Hill-Sachs lesion is a defect in the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head.
  • If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair.
  • They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rupture of tendon of supraspinatus muscle. This occurs due to repeated microtrauma or due to avulsion of the greater tuberosity. It is not associated with recurrent shoulder dislocation.

 

Option C. Avulsion of glenoid labrum. This is called Bankart’s lesion caused due to recurrent shoulder dislocation/subluxation. Here, the glenoid labrum is detached as the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hill-Sachs lesion from the recurrent shoulder dislocation involves the injury or fracture at the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head.

questions.text: Kocher manoeuver is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shoulder reduction

 

Option A)

 

KOCHER’S MAOEUVER

 

  • Commonly used reduction techniques for shoulder dislocation are Stimson's gravity method, Hippocratic method and Kocher's method.

 

 

  • Kochers method is done by traction in slight abduction and external rotation to increase deformity required to unlock the surfaces followed by adduction and internal rotation.
  • Post reduction, there is positioning of the limb in adduction and internal rotation, called as chest arm bandage x 3 weeks.
  • KOCHER Manoeuvre – TEAM
    • Traction
    • External Rotation
    • Adduction
    • Medial Rotation

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Elbow reduction. A traction-counter-traction technique is used under sedation and analgesia cover. The patient is kept in prone with the forearm dangling by the side. A downward traction is applied over the olecranon process while maintaining the elbow flexion. If done in supine position, with the forearm supinated, an axial traction is applied by slightly flexing the elbow. Post-reduction, the elbow is immobilized in 90â° flexion with forearm in neutral or pronation, in a long arm splint.

 

Option C. Ankle dislocation. Ankle dislocation is reduced with the patient in supine position and the foot at the end of the couch. One person grasps the calf muscle and applies a counter-traction while the other grasps the foot with one hand over the heel and other over the forefoot. For posterior dislocation reduction, slightly plantarflex the foot and distract the heel axially while maintaining the counter-traction. While maintaining the axial distraction, apply a counterforce to the ankle anteriorly, dorsiflex the foot and reposition the ankle joint. For anterior dislocation reduction, first dorsiflex the foot to distract talus and then apply axial traction and push foot backwards while maintaining the counter-traction to the posterior part of the leg. For lateral dislocation reduction, distract the heel axially, move the foot medially and dorsiflex it. Post-reduction, a long leg posterior splint with 90â° foot dorsiflexion is applied.

 

Option D. Knee dislocation. This is reduced with the patient in supine with the hip flexed, knee flexed to 120â° and internally rotated. A valgus force is applied to the distal thigh.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Kocher manoeuvre is used to reduce the shoulder by applying traction in abduction and external rotation, followed by adduction and internal rotation.

questions.text: Most common joint to be dislocated in the body is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shoulder

 

Option A)

 

JOINT DISLOCATION

 

  • The shoulder is the most regularly dislocated joint in the body.
  • The dislocation can occur anteriorly, posteriorly, inferiorly, or anterior-superiorly.
  • Anterior dislocations are the most common.
  • Patients with prior shoulder dislocation are more prone to redislocation. 
  • Recurrent dislocation is most common in shoulder joint, accounting for nearly 50% of all dislocations.
  • Most commonly, it is sub-coracoid type.
  • Second common joint for recurrent dislocation is patella and rarest joint to dislocate is ankle.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly dislocated joint in the body is the shoulder joint followed by the elbow joint.
  • Hip joint dislocations are rare and requires a huge amount of force to cause dislocation like a motor vehicle accident.
  •  Knee joint dislocations account for < 0.5% of all dislocations.

choices.text: Normal shoulder healing and movements

questions.text: What is the most common sequelae of traumatic shoulder dislocation in young adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent shoulder dislocation

 

Option B)

 

SEQUELAE OF TRAUMATIC SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Recurrent dislocation is most common in shoulder joint, accounting for nearly 50% of all dislocations.
  • Most commonly it is subcoracoid type.
  • Other complications include:
    • Muscle, ligament or tendon rupture
    • Nerve or blood vessel damage around the joint
    • Shoulder instability

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Frozen shoulder. Following dislocation, the shoulder shows some degree of limited motion owing to pain or apprehension for some time, which usually spontaneously recovers. However, some patients experience continuous stiffness after dislocation. This may lead to frozen shoulder if not mobilized early.

 

Option C. Normal shoulder healing and movements. The healing after the shoulder dislocation takes around 12-16 weeks. The movements are started slowly under the rehabilitation process.

 

Option D. Subscapular tendinitis. It is a rare complication of shoulder dislocation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common sequealae of the shoulder dislocation is the recurrence of the shoulder dislocation due to instability of the shoulder joint tissues.

questions.text: Putti Platt’s operation involves tightening of which muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subscapularis

 

Option B)

 

PUTTI PLATT’S OPERATION

 

  • It is a surgical procedure for stabilizing the glenohumeral joint after recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Subscapularis tendon and the anterior capsule are overlapped and tightened to the glenoid labrum.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the Putti-Platt procedure for the treatment of recurrent shoulder dislocation, the subscapularis tendon is tightened to improve stability of the joint.

choices.text: It is most common type of shoulder dislocation
It is most commonly subclavicular
Patient keeps his arm in saluting position
Injury to brachial plexus may occur

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anterior shoulder dislocation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is most common type of shoulder dislocation

 

Option A)

 

ANTERIOR SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Anterior dislocation: Abduction and External rotation force
  • Posterior dislocation: Indirect force producing marked internal rotation and adduction
  • Inferior dislocation: Severe hyperabduction force
  • Position of arm in shoulder dislocation:
    • Anterior Dislocation (Sub-coracoid > Pre-glenoid > Sub-clavicular type): Slight abduction and external rotation
  • Most commonly injured nerve in anterior dislocation of shoulder is circumflex branch of axillary nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. It is most commonly subclavicular. False. Anterior shoulder dislocation is common in subcoracoid, followed by pre-glenoid and subclavicular type.

 

Option C. Patient keeps his arm in saluting position. False. The patient keeps their arm in slight abduction and external rotation.

 

Option D. Injury to brachial plexus may occur. False. In anterior shoulder dislocation, the most commonly injured nerve is the circumflex branch of the axillary nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common type of shoulder dislocation.

questions.text: Hamilton Ruler test sign is positive in which of the above-mentioned conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior dislocation of shoulder

 

Option A)

 

HAMILTON RULER TEST

 

 

  • Hamilton's ruler sign is positive when the tip of the acromion joined to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus with a straight line.
  • This indicates a dislocated shoulder, with the resulting loss of the normal prominence of the humeral head.
  • Because of flattening of shoulder, it is possible to place a ruler on the lateral side of arm and it touches acromion and lateral condyle of humerus simultaneously (in normal it would not due to shoulder contour).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hamilton ruler test sign is positive in anterior dislocation of the shoulder.

choices.text: A defect in the anterior-inferior capsule

questions.text: Which of the following Defect (lesion) is NOT responsible for recurrent anterior dislocation of shoulder?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bristow's lesion

 

Option C)

 

RECURRENT SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Differences between recurrent and non-recurrent anterior dislocation:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bankart’s lesion and Option B. Hill-Sachs lesion are commonly responsible for recurrent shoulder dislocation.

 

Option D. A defect in anterior-inferior capsule is relatively uncommon to cause recurrent shoulder dislocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bristow’s lesion is not a responsible cause for recurrent shoulder dislocation.
  • It is a surgical procedure done to address shoulder instability where the coracoid process is transferred to the glenoid rim.
  • Bankart’s lesion and Hill-Sachs lesion occurs due to recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Antero-inferior capsular defect makes the shoulder joint more prone to recurrent dislocations.

questions.text: All are seen in anterior shoulder dislocation except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elevated anterior axillary fold

 

Option A)

 

ANTERIOR SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Patient keeps his arm slightly abducted.
  • Normal round contour of shoulder is lost and it becomes flat.
  • Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at lower level.
  • Dugas test: It is not possible for the patient to bring the elbow close to the body and touch the tip of opposite shoulder.
  • Callaway's test: Vertical circumference of axilla is increased as compared to the normal side.
  • Hamilton ruler test: Because of flattening of shoulder, it is possible to place a ruler on the lateral side of arm and it touches acromion and lateral condyle of humerus simultaneously (in normal it would not due to shoulder contour).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the anterior shoulder dislocation, the anterior axillary fold is at a lower level.
  • The Dugas and Hamilton ruler tests are positive.
  • There is an increased vertical circumference of the axilla as compared to the normal side – Callaway’s test.

questions.text: Commonest type of shoulder dislocation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subcoracoid

 

Option A)

 

SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • The most common type of shoulder dislocation is the anterior dislocation followed by posterior dislocation.
  • Among the anterior Dislocation, Subcoracoid > Preglenoid > Subclavicular type.
  • Subglenoid is the other name for the inferior dislocation, which is the least commonly seen shoulder dislocation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common type of anterior dislocation of the shoulder is subcoracoid type followed by preglenoid and subclavicular types.
  • Posterior dislocation and subglenoid/inferior dislocation are least commonly seen.

questions.text: Uncomplicated shoulder dislocation most commonly occurs in the following direction:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

Option A)

 

SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Anterior dislocation: Abduction and External rotation force
  • Posterior dislocation: Indirect force producing marked internal rotation and adduction
  • Inferior dislocation: Severe hyperabduction force
  • Position of arm in shoulder dislocation
    1. Anterior Dislocation (Subcoracoid > Preglenoid > Subclavicular type):
      • Slight abduction and external rotation
    2. Posterior Dislocation:
      • Difficult to diagnose because the patient may have normal contour of shoulder. Holds injured arm.
    3. Inferior Dislocation (Luxatio erecta/Subglenoid):
      • Locked in full abduction, fixed by the side of head.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The uncomplicated shoulder dislocation occurs in the anterior direction.

questions.text: Nerve injured in anterior dislocation of shoulder is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Axillary nerve 

 

Option B)

 

NERVE INJURY IN SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Most common early complication of anterior dislocation of shoulder is nerve injury.
  • Most commonly injured nerve in anterior dislocation of shoulder is circumflex branch of axillary nerve.
  • The injury to nerve is usually neuropraxia.
  • In Inferior dislocation also, axillary nerve involvement is the commonest.
  • Other Nerves Rarely Involved are:
    • Musculocutaneous nerve
    • Radial nerve
    • Avulsion of brachial plexus

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Radial nerve is rarely involved in anterior shoulder dislocation.

 

Option C. Long thoracic nerve and Option D. Median nerve. They are not involved in shoulder dislocation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly injured nerve in anterior shoulder dislocation is the axillary nerve.

questions.text: Neglected shoulder dislocation in a young labourer is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgically managed

 

Option B)

 

SURGERIES FOR RECURRENT DISLOCATION OF SHOULDER

 

1. Bankart’s operation: Detached anterior structures are attached to the rim of the glenoid cavity with suture.
 


 

2. Putti Platt’s operation: Subscapularis tendon and capsule is overlapped and tightened.

 


 

3. Laterjet Bristow’s operation: Transplantation of coracoid process with its attachments to the anterior rim of glenoid.

 

4. Neer’s capsular shift for multidirectional instability.

 

5. In failed reconstructions, glenoid deficiency may be treated with the Laterjet procedure or iliac crest bone graft.

 

6. Neglected shoulder dislocation – Surgically managed.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A neglected dislocation is a challenging condition, as the soft tissue contracture around the joint, fibrosis in the glenoid fossa, and bony lesions in both glenoid and humerus complicate the management.
  • Also, as the dislocation is commonly locked, it is unlikely to achieve a closed reduction in such cases. 
  • The most common treatment option is surgical management. It can be done by open reduction.

questions.text: In Recurrent Anterior dislocation of shoulder, the movements that causes dislocation are:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abduction and external rotation

 

Option B)

 

RECURRENT ANTERIOR SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Abduction and extreme of external rotation causes recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Recurrent shoulder dislocation is caused by abduction and external rotation movements.

questions.text: Recurrent dislocations are least commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankle

 

Option A)

 

RECURRENT DISLOCATIONS

 

  • Recurrent dislocation is most common in shoulder joint, accounting for nearly 50% of all dislocations.
  • Second common joint for recurrent dislocation is patella and rarest joint to dislocate is ankle.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Recurrent dislocations are least common in the ankle joint.

questions.text: All are related to recurrent shoulder dislocation except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rotator cuff injury

 

Option D)

 

RECURRENT SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Differences between recurrent and non-recurrent anterior dislocation:

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Bankart’s and Hill-Sachs lesion and lax capsule are commonly associated with recurrent shoulder dislocation while the rotator cuff injury is rarely associated.

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is caused by impingement of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rotator cuff tendon

 

Option C)

 

PAINFUL ARC SYNDROME

 

  • Painful arc syndrome occurs when the rotator cuff impinges on the coracoacromial arch (external) or glenoid (internal).
  • It is a condition characterized by pain and discomfort during a specific range of motion of the shoulder joint.
  • It is often associated with Impingement syndrome.
  • Generally, the pain occurs during mid-abduction (60â° to 120â°).
  • Causes:
    • Rotator cuff tendinitis
    • Subacromial bursitis
    • Rotator cuff impingement
  • Management:
    • Rest and Analgesics
    • Physical Therapy
    • Surgical intervention

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Subacromial bursa: The subacromial bursa is a small, fluid-filled sac located between the acromion and the rotator cuff tendons. Its primary function is to reduce friction and provide cushioning during shoulder movement. However, inflammation or irritation of the subacromial bursa, known as subacromial bursitis, can occur due to repetitive overhead activities or trauma. While subacromial bursitis can lead to shoulder pain and discomfort, it is not typically associated with painful arc syndrome.

 

Option B. Subdeltoid bursa: The subdeltoid bursa is a small sac filled with fluid, located between the deltoid muscle and the underlying joint structures of the shoulder. Its function is similar to that of other bursae, providing cushioning and reducing friction during shoulder movement. Inflammation or irritation of the subdeltoid bursa, known as subdeltoid bursitis, can occur due to overuse, trauma, or underlying conditions such as arthritis. However, impingement of the subdeltoid bursa is not typically associated with painful arc syndrome.

 

Option D. Biceps tendon: The biceps tendon is a strong cord-like structure that attaches the biceps muscle to the shoulder and elbow joints. It plays a crucial role in the movement of the shoulder and elbow. Impingement or irritation of the biceps tendon can occur within the shoulder joint, particularly in the region known as the bicipital groove. This can lead to a condition called biceps tendinitis, characterized by pain and inflammation in the front of the shoulder. While biceps tendinitis can cause shoulder pain, it is not typically associated with painful arc syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Painful arc syndrome is commonly caused by the impingement of the rotator cuff tendons.

questions.text: Traumatic glenohumeral instability in one direction with Bankart’s lesion is treated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgery

 

Option B)

 

SHOULDER INSTABILITY

 

  • Treatment of traumatic unidirectional instability – Surgery.
  • Treatment of non-traumatic multidirectional instability – Rehabilitation.
  • Management of Glenohumeral instability:

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Treatment of traumatic glenohumeral instability in one direction with bankart’s lesion is surgery.

questions.text: Following anterior dislocation of the shoulder, a patient develops weakness of flexion at elbow and lack of sensation over the lateral aspect forearm. The nerve injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Musculocutaneous nerve

 

Option B)

 

NERVE INJURY

 

  • The most common complication of anterior dislocation of shoulder is axillary (circumflex) nerve injury.
  • There is consequent paralysis of the deltoid muscle, with a small area of anaesthesia at the lateral aspect of the upper arm.
  • However, in this question the sensations are lost on lateral aspect of forearm (not arm).
  • Lateral side of forearm has sensory supply from lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm, a branch of musculocutaneous nerve.
  • Musculocutaneous nerve also supplies the biceps brachii (a flexor of elbow joint).
  • Therefore, musculocutaneous nerve injury will cause sensory loss over lateral aspect of the forearm with weakness of flexion at elbow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Radial nerve. If damaged at the axilla, there will be a loss of extension of the forearm, hand, and fingers. Thus, this usually presents with a wrist drop on physical examination. There will be a sensory loss in the lateral arm, and posterior aspect of the forearm, radiating to the radial aspect of the dorsal hand and digits. 

 

Option C. Axillary nerve. This causes deltoid weakness and sensation loss at the lateral aspect of the upper arm.

 

Option D. Ulnar nerve. The patient may have numbness and paresthesia, radiating distally to the ulnar aspect of the hand, the fifth digit and the ulnar aspect of the fourth digit. It is usually associated with elbow flexion. Sensory symptoms involve the fifth digit and medial half of the fourth digit.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described features in the question of weak elbow flexion and lack of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm are indicative of musculocutaneous nerve injury.

choices.text: Tear of the glenoid labrum

questions.text: Luxatio erecta is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior dislocation of shoulder

 

Option B)

 

LUXATIO ERECTA

 

  • Inferior (Downward/subglenoid) dislocation of shoulder is known as luxation erecta.
  • It is caused by severe hyper abduction force.
  • With the humerus as the lever and acromion as fulcrum, the humeral head is lifted across the inferior rim of glenoid socket and pokes into axilla (subglenoid position).
  • The patient comes with his forearm resting on hand.
  • Potentially serious consequences, e.g., neurovascular damage is quite common (Axillary nerve injured).
  • Reduced by pulling upwards in the line of abducted arm with counter traction downwards.
  • It is usually indicative of hyperlaxity syndrome and usually such patients have multidirectional instability.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tear of glenoid labrum. This is known as Bankart’s lesion.

 

Option D. Defect in the humeral head. This is known as Hill-Sachs lesion.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Luxatio erecta is known as inferior dislocation of the shoulder.

questions.text: Light bulb sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of shoulder

 

Option B)

 

LIGHT BULB SIGN

 

  • Investigation Reliance is placed on a single A-P X-ray which may look almost normal.
  • In A-P X-ray view, medially rotated head looks abnormal (electric bulb sign) and it stands away from glenoid fossa (empty glenoid sign).
  • Reverse Hill Sach’s Lesion may be seen on the antero-medial aspect of humerus.

 

 

 

X-ray: posterior dislocation

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior dislocation of shoulder. Anterior shoulder dislocation may show Hill-Sachs or Bankart’s lesion on the x-ray of the shoulder.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Light bulb sign is seen in the posterior dislocation of the shoulder, where the humeral head looks abnormal.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was unconscious and presented with bilateral adduction and internal rotation of shoulder. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation

 

Option B)

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF SHOULDER

 

  • Mechanism of Injury is an indirect force producing marked internal rotation and adduction, most commonly during a fit, convulsion or an electric shock.
  • Clinical presentation is often missed clinically.
  • The classical clinical feature is that the arm is locked in medial rotation, and the examiner cannot externally rotate it.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior dislocation. The mechanism of injury is an abduction and external rotation force. The patient keeps the arm in slight abduction. The normal round contour of the shoulder is lost, and the shoulder looks flat.

 

Option D. Brachial plexus injury. The mechanism of injury can be traumatic (e.g., motor vehicle accident, contact sports) or non-traumatic (e.g., obstetric palsy, parsonage Turner syndrome) due to stretching of the plexus or crushing of plexus. The patient may present with Erb’s palsy/Klumpke’s palsy/claw hand depending on the site of the injury to the plexus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given clinical presentation of the patient of bilateral adduction and internal rotation of the shoulder is characteristic of posterior dislocation of the shoulder.

questions.text: In posterior dislocation of shoulder, Reverse Hill Sach lesion is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anteromedial

 

Option B)

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF SHOULDER

 

  • Investigation Reliance is placed on a single A-P X-ray which may look almost normal.

  • In A-P X-ray because of medial rotation head looks abnormal (electric bulb sign) and it stands away somewhat from glenoid fossa (empty glenoid sign).

 

 

  • Reverse Hill-Sach Lesion may be seen on the anteromedial aspect of humerus.

  • McLaughlin procedure is done for recurrent posterior shoulder dislocation with reverse Hill Sachs lesion.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the posterior dislocation of the shoulder, a reverse Hill-Sachs lesion is seen in the anteromedial location.

questions.text: Which of the following is test of posterior glenohumeral instability?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Jerk test

 

Option C)

 

POSTERIOR INSTABILITY TESTS

 

Test for Posterior Instability (Adduction and internal rotation force) are:

 

  • Jerk (provocative) test

 

 

  • Posterior apprehension test
  • Posterior clunk test
  • Push-Pull test

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fulcrum test. Fulcrum Test is an apprehension test for anterior shoulder instability.

 

Option B. Sulcus test. This test is done to evaluate inferior shoulder instability.

 

Option D. Crank test. This is also an apprehension test for anterior shoulder instability.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Out of the given choices, Jerk test is used to test the posterior glenohumeral instability.

questions.text: In the shoulder X-ray, highest bony landmark is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acromion

 

Option D)

 

  • Acromion, which is a part of scapula, is the highest point on a shoulder x-ray.
  • If clavicle is mentioned in the question, then it is even higher.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Greater tuberosity. This is a prominent bony projection on the proximal end of the humerus. It serves as the attachment site for muscles and ligaments of the shoulder joint.

 

Option B. Lesser tuberosity. This is a bony prominence on the anterior surface of the humerus, smaller than the greater tuberosity. Like the greater tuberosity, it serves as a site for muscle attachment.

 

Option C. Head of the humerus. The head of the humerus is the rounded part of the bone that fits into the shallow socket of the scapula, forming the ball-and-socket joint of the shoulder.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Acromion is the highest point on the shoulder x-ray.
  • If the question mentions clavicle in the options, then it will be the correct answer as it is higher than the acromion.

questions.text: The most common bone fractured during birth is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clavicle

 

Option A)

 

  • Clavicle is the most common fractured bone (overall) in adults and during birth.
  • Clavicle is the 4th common fractured bone in children after distal radius and ulna; hand injuries; elbow injuries in order of priority.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Radius. Neonatal radius fracture can occur due to shoulder dystocia or from manoeuvres employed to alleviate shoulder dystocia.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most commonly fractured bone during the birth is the clavicle.

choices.text: Open Reduction and Internal fixation

questions.text: Clavicular fracture is usually treated by
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Figure of eight bandage

 

Option C)

 

CLAVICLE FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Sling immobilization/Figure of eight bandage is adequate non-operative treatment for most isolated clavicle fractures.

 

  • Malunion is the most common complication.
  • Surgical treatment of clavicle fractures is generally reserved for fractures of the lateral clavicle, middle third fractures with >2 cm of shortening, open fractures, symptomatic non-unions, or fractures with associated neurovascular injury, in patients with a floating shoulder or other complex injuries to the shoulder girdle where addressing the clavicle may improve overall stability of the upper extremity.
  • Surgical options are plating and K-wire fixation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Traction. Clavicular fractures are typically not treated with traction because the clavicle is relatively easy to immobilize and stabilize with other methods.

 

Option B. Open reduction and internal fixation. There are a very few specific indications in which ORIF is indicated. In a complex or displaced fracture, this treatment method can be used.

 

Option D. Plate and screw fixation. It is a form of ORIF procedure that can be used for displaced or complex fractures.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Clavicle fractures are treated easily by a figure of eight bandage.

questions.text: What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neer classification grade 4

 

Option A)

 

NEER CLASSIFICATION OF PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • Displaced injuries of proximal humerus are best classified by the system developed by Neer and are labelled two, three or four-part fractures.
  • The four potential parts are the humeral head, the greater tuberosity, the lesser tuberosity, and the shaft.
