Diagram of (A) the normal and (B) a fractured proximal humerus, showing the four main fragments, showing the four main fragments, two or more of which are seen in almost all proximal humeral fractures 1-shaft of humerus; 2-head of humerus; 3-greater tuberosity; 4-lesser tuberosity.

 

  • Displacement:
    • Displacement is on a per-part basis.
    • A fracture part is considered displaced if angulation exceeds 45°, or if the fracture is displaced by more than 1 cm.
    • The simplest displaced fracture is a two-part fracture.
    • A minimally displaced fracture, even one with multiple fracture lines, merely constitutes a type I, one-part fracture.
  • Classification:
    • The classification consists of four major groupings, based on the number of displaced parts.
    • Neer added a fifth group more recently.
    • One-part fracture:
      • Fracture lines involves 1 to 4 parts
      • None of the parts are displaced (i.e. <1 cm and <45°)
      • Non-displaced or minimally displaced fractures
      • Account for ~70-80% of all proximal humeral fractures
      • Almost always treated conservatively
    • Two-part fracture:
      • Fracture lines involves 2 to 4 parts
      • One part is displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
      • Four possible types of two-part fractures exist (one for each part):
        1. Surgical neck: most common
        2. Greater tuberosity: frequently seen in the anterior shoulder dislocation – lower threshold of displacement (>5 mm) present
        3. Anatomical neck
        4. Lesser tuberosity: uncommon
      • Accounts for 20% of proximal humeral fractures
    • Three-part fracture:
      • Fracture lines involves 3 or 4 parts
      • Two parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
      • Two three-part fracture patterns are encountered:
        1. Greater tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the lesser tuberosity and articular surface remain together – most common
        2. Lesser tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the greater tuberosity and articular surface remain together
      • Account for 5% of proximal humeral fractures
    • Four-part fracture:
      • Fracture lines involves all 4 parts
      • Three parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°) with respect to the 4th
      • Uncommon (<1% of proximal humeral fractures)
      • Poor non-operative results as the articular surface is not attached to any part of the humerus
      • High incidence of osteonecrosis
      • Require operative management
    • Valgus impacted four-part fracture

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ideberg classification grade 4. The Ideberg classification system is the most common system used to describe glenoid fossa and rim fractures. The classification was initially created on AP and lateral radiographs of the shoulder, but are now assessed on CT.

 

 

 

Thus, type IV of this classification involves fracture line through glenoid fossa that exits the scapula medially.

 

Option C. Garden classification grade 3. The Garden classification of subcapital femoral neck fractures predicts the development of osteonecrosis. It describes the femoral neck and acetabular trabeculae patterns.

 

 

 

Thus, stage 3 of this classification involves a complete fracture of the femoral neck which is incompletely displaced.

 

Option D. Schatzker classification grade 5. Schatzker classification system classifies tibial plateau fractures. Increase in type number denotes increasing severity, reflecting an increase in energy imparted to the bone at the time of injury and also an increasingly worse prognosis.

 

 

 

Thus, grade 5 of this classification involves wedge fracture of both lateral and medial tibial plateaus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows the fracture of the proximal humerus.
  • The type of fracture according to Neer’s classification is grade 4 involving fracture of all 4 parts of the joint.

questions.text: A patient had met with an accident and he cannot abduct his right arm and cannot lift it. On examination, tenderness felt near right upper arm. X-ray showed fracture surgical neck of humerus. Muscle that was paralysed was:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supraspinatus

 

Option B)

 

  • The best answer here is deltoid or teres minor (axillary nerve).
  • Since it is not mentioned, so we choose supraspinatus (suprascapular nerve).

 

Note: The most common nerve involved in neck humerus fracture is axillary nerve (supplies deltoid and teres minor). The next common nerve involved is suprascapular nerve (supplies supraspinatus—abductor and infraspinatus—external rotator)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly injured nerve in the fracture neck of humerus is the axillary nerve followed by the suprascapular nerve.
  • The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles while the suprascapular nerve supplies the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles.
  • So, if one of the choices includes deltoid/teres minor/infraspinatus/supraspinatus muscles in such case scenario questions, then they will be considered the correct answer.

questions.text: In fracture of surgical neck of humerus, which nerve is involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axillary nerve

 

Option A)

 

NERVE INJURED IN FRACTURE SURGICAL NECK OF HUMERUS

 

  • The most common nerve involved in neck humerus fracture is axillary nerve (supplies deltoid and teres minor).
  • The next common nerve involved is suprascapular nerve (supplies supraspinatus—abductor and infraspinatus—external rotator)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly injured nerve in fracture surgical neck of humerus is axillary nerve > suprascapular nerve.

questions.text: Most common complication of mid shaft humerus fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial nerve palsy

 

Option A)

 

COMPLICATION OF HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • Remember, only 2.5% cases have radial nerve palsy (RNP).
  • The two complications often seen are injuries to the radial nerve and non-union of the fracture.
  • Radial Nerve Injury:
    • Injuries to the radial nerve are fairly common in a mid-shaft fracture of humerus because this important nerve tightly wraps around the middle of the humerus. 
    • The radial nerve can be injured at the time of the fracture or during treatment.
    • Radial nerve injuries cause:
      • Numbness on the back of the hand
      • Difficulty extending the wrist and fingers
    • Most radial nerve injuries typically improve with time.
  • Non-union:
    • Non-union is a difficult problem and can happen for many reasons.
    • One of the most common reasons for non-union is surgeryï»¿.
    • After the surgery, the soft tissues surrounding the fracture are further disrupted, and this can compromise blood flow to the site of the fracture.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Medial nerve palsy. Median and ulnar nerve palsies are rare following humerus shaft fracture.

 

Option C. Non-union. This is usually seen following the surgical treatment of the fracture.

 

Option D. Malunion. This can be seen with transverse fracture pattern but is not usually a common complication.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common complication of the mid-shaft humerus fracture is the radial nerve palsy.

questions.text: Which type of proximal humerus fracture has maximum chances of avascular necrosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Four-part

 

Option D)

 

PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • Four-part fractures are at very high risk for development of complete osteonecrosis of the humeral head, resulting in functional limitation.
  • For this reason, hemiarthroplasty of the shoulder is usually considered.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. One-part. One-part fracture without displacement is considered as a partial fracture. Thus, it is a least serious fracture and can be treated conservatively.

 

Option B. Two-part. This fracture, if involves the greater tuberosity, has a higher risk of disability of the overhead shoulder movement, if not treated timely.

 

Option C. Three-part. This type of fracture may lead to avascular necrosis but the chances are less than the four-part fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Four-part fracture of the proximal humerus has the maximum chances of avascular necrosis of the humeral head.

choices.text: Ulnar nerve
Median nerve
Radial nerve

questions.text: The most common nerve involved in posterior dislocation of elbow is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulnar nerve

 

Option A)

 

POSTERIOR ELBOW DISLOCATION

 

  • In elbow dislocation, posterior type is common.
  • The most common neurovascular structures injured during an elbow dislocation include the brachial artery and the ulnar nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Median nerve. Median nerve entrapment following an elbow dislocation is a very rare entity.

 

Option C. Radial nerve. It can be also injured in the elbow dislocation but not common than ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. The musculocutaneous nerve arises from the brachial plexus and innervates the muscles in the front of the upper arm. It does not directly pass over the elbow joint and is less likely to be involved in posterior dislocation compared to other nerves in the region.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly injured nerve in posterior dislocation of elbow is the ulnar nerve.

choices.text: Analgesic with triangular sling

questions.text: Treatment of choice for fracture neck of humerus in a 70-year-old male is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Analgesic with triangular sling

 

Option A)

 

TREATMENT OF FRACTURE NECK OF HUMERUS

 

  • Decision is taken on:
  1. Activity of the patient
  2. Level of comminution
  3. Osteoporosis
  4. Comorbidities
  • Non-operative management is typically preferred for elderly patients with minimal displacement, while operative fixation is considered for more complex fractures.
  • Certain fracture patterns, such as one-part lesser or greater tuberosity fractures, impacted two-part surgical neck fractures, and one-part humeral neck fractures are good candidates for non-operative management.
  • Non-operative treatment involves analgesics for pain relief along with sling immobilization followed by physiotherapy, with good outcomes reported for certain fracture patterns.
  • Options for immobilization include cuff and collar, standard sling, hanging arm cast, shoulder spica cast, and airplane splint; however, hanging arm and shoulder spica casts are not utilized clinically anymore. 
  • Triangular splints are considered now-a-days.
  • Functional bracing is not effective for PHFs, unlike humeral shaft fractures, as the rotator cuff pull on the fracture fragments causing a deforming force that cannot be neutralized externally. 

 

Note: If the question does not mention about age or classification, then treatment of choice will be sling and analgesics as this is very commonly seen in osteoporotic females and it is very often impacted in them.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. U-slab. This treatment method may not offer sufficient stability for a fracture neck of the humerus, particularly in an elderly individual who may have compromised bone density.

 

Option C. Arthroplasty. Arthroplasty may be considered if the fracture is severe or displaced, Comminuted, or angulated.

 

Option D. Open reduction internal fixation. ORIF is often considered the treatment of choice for displaced or unstable fractures of the neck of the humerus, particularly in younger, active patients or those with good bone quality. However, in older individuals with poorer bone quality or medical comorbidities, the decision to proceed with surgery must be carefully weighed against the risks.

 

Educational objective:

 

The treatment of choice for a 70-year-old patient with humerus neck fracture is conservative with analgesics and a triangular splint.

choices.text: Abduction and lateral rotation
Adduction and medial rotation

questions.text: Which of the following movements will be affected if the greater tubercle of the humerus is lost?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abduction and lateral rotation

 

Option A)

 

  • Supraspinatus, infraspinatus and teres minor have attachment to the greater tuberosity which causes abduction and external rotation.
  • Fractures of the greater tuberosity must be treated with open reduction and internal fixation, if displaced more than 3-5 mm, because there is increased risk of disability of overhead function especially abduction and external rotation (Supraspinatus Assists deltoid in abduction and Infraspinatus/Teres minor laterally (externally) rotates arm).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Adduction and flexion. Pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, and teres major are the muscles primarily responsible for shoulder adduction. The main flexors of the shoulder are the anterior deltoid, coracobrachialis, and pectoralis major. These muscles do not have an attachment on the greater tuberosity of the humerus, thus these movements are not affected by the loss of the tuberosity.

 

Option C. Adduction and medial rotation. Pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, and teres major are the muscles primarily responsible for shoulder adduction. The internal rotation muscles are the subscapularis, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, teres major, and the anterior aspect of the deltoid. These muscles do not have an attachment on the greater tuberosity of the humerus, thus these movements are not affected by the loss of the tuberosity.

 

Option D. Flexion and medial rotation. The main flexors of the shoulder are the anterior deltoid, coracobrachialis, and pectoralis major. The internal rotation muscles are the subscapularis, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, teres major, and the anterior aspect of the deltoid. These muscles do not have an attachment on the greater tuberosity of the humerus, thus these movements are not affected by the loss of the tuberosity.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • If the greater tuberosity of the humerus is lost, the movements affected are abduction and lateral rotation of the shoulder because these movements are controlled by the supraspinatus, infraspinatus and teres minor muscles which are attached on the greater tuberosity.

questions.text: Fracture neck humerus is common in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elderly woman

 

Option A)

 

FRACTURE NECK OF HUMERUS

 

  • Proximal humeral fractures are relatively common and occur most often as the result of falls or motor vehicle trauma.
  • The incidence increases with age and in the elderly, the cause is typically a low-energy injury.
  • Elderly osteoporotic females are usually involved. In such cases, it is usually impacted.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Young lady. Fracture neck of the humerus can occur in individuals of all ages, including younger individuals. However, it is less common in younger populations compared to elderly individuals. In younger individuals, fractures of the humerus are more likely to occur as a result of high-energy trauma, such as motor vehicle accidents.

 

Option C. Children. Fracture neck of the humerus is less common in children compared to adults. In pediatric populations, fractures of the humerus are more likely to occur in the shaft of the bone rather than the neck. However, fracture neck of the humerus can still occur in children, especially in cases of significant trauma or in certain medical conditions that affect bone health.

 

Educational objective:

 

While fracture neck of the humerus can occur in young women and children, it is less common in these populations compared to elderly individuals. Thus, elderly, osteoporotic females are more commonly affected.

choices.text: If a bone is continuously subjected to a particular stress, it will adapt to become stronger to resist that loading.
Only Diaphysis allows longitudinal growth in childhood.
Any infection not showing periosteal reaction within 1 week of symptoms can be ruled out to be osteomyelitis.
Angular deformities will progress till the closure of physis.

questions.text: Wolff’s law states that:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) If a bone is continuously subjected to a particular stress, it will adapt to become stronger to resist that loading.

 

Option A)

 

WOLFF’S LAW

 

  • Our bones are constantly changing.
  • On application of stress, the bones remodel themselves to adapt to the stresses.
  • The Wolff’s law states that bones will adapt to a degree of mechanical loading, such that an increase in loading will cause the architecture of the internal, spongy bone to strengthen, followed by strengthening of the cortical layer.
  • This adaptation occurs through the process of bone remodelling, where osteoclasts resorb bone tissue in areas of low stress, and osteoblasts deposit new bone tissue in response to mechanical stress, thereby reshaping the bone to better suit its functional demands.
  • A decrease in stress on the bone will cause these bone layers to weaken.
  • The duration, magnitude and rate of forces applied to the bone dictate how the integrity of the bone is altered.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Only Diaphysis allows longitudinal growth in childhood. This statement refers to the process of longitudinal growth in bones during childhood, which primarily occurs at the growth plates (epiphyseal plates) located near the ends (epiphyses) of long bones, rather than specifically in the diaphysis (the shaft of a long bone). While it pertains to bone growth, it does not relate to Wolff's law.

 

Option C. Any infection not showing periosteal reaction within 1 week of symptoms can be ruled out to be osteomyelitis. This statement concerns the diagnostic criteria for osteomyelitis. It mentions the presence or absence of periosteal reaction, which is an imaging finding associated with osteomyelitis but not with Wolff's law.

 

Option D. Angular deformities will progress till the closure of physis. This statement refers to angular deformities in bones that occur during growth and development, particularly at the growth plates or physis. It suggests that angular deformities will continue to progress until the growth plates close. This statement does not specifically relate to Wolff's law.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Wolff’s law states that if a bone is continuously subjected to a particular stress, it will adapt to that stress to become stronger to resist the loading.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely associated with vascular injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fracture shaft humerus

 

Option D)

 

VASCULAR INJURY

 

  • RNP (Radial nerve palsy) is more common.
  • Fractures in this area are less likely to directly injure major blood vessels due to deeper vessel location and protection from surrounding musculature.
  • However, severe fractures or traumatic injuries can still potentially lead to vascular injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fracture supracondylar femur. The supracondylar region of the femur is near the knee joint. Fractures in this area can potentially injure the popliteal artery, a major blood vessel behind the knee. Depending on the severity and nature of the fracture, vascular injury is a possibility.

 

Option B. Fracture supracondylar humerus. The supracondylar region of the humerus is near the elbow joint. Fractures in this area can potentially injure the brachial artery, a major blood vessel in the arm. Vascular injury is a concern, particularly if the fracture is displaced or involves significant trauma.

 

Option C. Fracture shaft of femur. The femoral shaft does not typically have major blood vessels running directly adjacent to it. Vascular injury in this region is less common compared to fractures near the joints where major blood vessels are located. Fractures of the femoral shaft may cause bleeding from the bone itself or adjacent soft tissues, but direct injury to major blood vessels is less likely.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Following the fracture of shaft of humerus, vascular injury is least common but the nerve injury is more common and the most commonly injured nerve is the radial nerve.

choices.text: Most common early complication of anterior dislocation shoulder is nerve injury
Hill Sachs is seen in recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation
Rotator cuff injury is a common cause of recurrent dislocation
Posterior dislocation presents with difficulty in external rotation of shoulder

questions.text: About Shoulder dislocation, false is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rotator cuff injury is a common cause of recurrent dislocation

 

Option C)

 

  • Rotator cuff tears are more commonly a result of a dislocation, especially in older patients, rather than a cause of recurrent dislocation.
  • In young individuals, recurrent dislocations are typically due to capsulolabral injuries, like a Bankart lesion (tear of the anterior inferior labrum).
  • Therefore, the statement â€œRotator cuff injury is a common cause of recurrent dislocationâ€ is incorrect.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Most common early complication of anterior dislocation shoulder is nerve injury: True. The most commonly injured nerve is the axillary nerve, which runs close to the shoulder joint. It can be stretched or compressed during dislocation, leading to sensory loss over the deltoid region and weakness in shoulder abduction. This is indeed the most frequent early complication.

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs is seen in recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation: True. A Hill-Sachs lesion is a compression fracture of the posterolateral humeral head. It occurs when the dislocated humeral head impacts against the anterior edge of the glenoid. It is commonly associated with recurrent anterior dislocations.

 

Option D. Posterior dislocation presents with difficulty in external rotation of shoulder: True. In posterior dislocation, the shoulder is typically locked in internal rotation, and the patient is unable to externally rotate the arm. This is a classic presentation and often leads to misdiagnosis if not specifically looked for.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common cause of the recurrent shoulder dislocation is the presence of a Bankartâ€™s or Hill-Sachs lesion.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is diagnosed to have irreparable tear of the rotator cuff. Treatment of choice will be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tendon transfer

 

Option A)

 

ROTATOR CUFF TREATMENT

 

  • The treatment of choice in symptomatic cases is the direct reattachment of the torn tendon to the foot-print through either open or arthroscopic surgery.
  • However, some tears can progress to the point of becoming irreparable. 
  • The term irreparable is often incorrectly used and ably interchanged with the term massive.
  • It is possible to define irreparable tears as those that, because of their size and retraction, cannot be repaired primarily to their insertion on the tuberosities despite conventional techniques of mobilization and soft-tissue releases.
  • Moreover, irreparable RCT typically present with atrophy and fatty degeneration of the respective muscles that lead to impaired muscle quality and thus to defective contraction, even if direct repairs are structurally successful.
  • Surgical options include arthroscopic debridement with or without partial rotator cuff repair, the use of rotator cuff allografts and synthetic grafts, arthroplasty and tendon transfer.

 

 

  • Tendon transfer procedures:
    • The choice of the most appropriate procedure depends on the presenting symptoms (pain and/or disability), age of the patient, functional demand, medical comorbidities, joint stability and presence of arthritic changes.
    • The ideal candidate for a tendon transfer procedure is a young, active patient who does not have glenohumeral osteoarthritis but has severe disability related to weakness and loss of external rotation.
    • The selection of the donor muscle-tendon unit is based on the structural deficit and impaired function.
    • The most commonly used muscle-tendon units for transfer include the latissimus dorsi for posterosuperior RCT and the pectoralis major for irreparable anterosuperior tears.
    • Aim of tendon transfer is to restore the force couples of the shoulder.
    • With Latissimus Dorsi transfer, the aim is to exert an external rotation force that allows for a more balanced state in the glenohumeral joint and thus, replacing the function of the posterior force couple.
    • Aim of Pectoralis Major transfer is to exert an internal rotation centering force thereby, replacing the function of the subscapularis. This is intended to function as the anterior force couple.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Total shoulder replacement. Total shoulder arthroplasty is contraindicated in cases of irreparable rotator cuff tears because of risk of loosening of the glenoid prosthesis.


Option C. Reverse shoulder replacement. Although reverse shoulder arthroplasty reliably improves function and relieves pain in irreparable rotator cuff tears (RCTs), the long-term outcomes in active, high demand patients remains unknown. Non-arthroplasty options represent a challenging but attractive alternative as no long term restrictions are required. Attempted repair has been associated with retear rates exceeding 90%, challenging the utility of repair in this scenario. Several non-arthroplasty treatment options have variable success including biceps tenotomy or tenodesis, subacromial decompression, partial rotator cuff repair, superior capsular reconstruction and tendon transfer. Tendon transfers provide durable and dynamic treatment option for the active high demand patient with an irreparable RCT.

 

Option D. Acromioplasty. Acromioplasty is a surgical procedure aimed at removing a portion of the acromion. This procedure is often performed in cases of subacromial impingement syndrome, where the rotator cuff tendons become pinched or irritated beneath the acromion during certain shoulder movements. While acromioplasty can be a part of the surgical management for rotator cuff tears, it is not typically considered the treatment of choice for irreparable tears. Acromioplasty alone does not address the underlying issue of the irreparable tear and may not provide sufficient pain relief or functional improvement in these cases.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The treatment of choice in a young, active patient with irreparable rotator cuff tear, without glenohumeral joint arthritis is tendon transfer using the latissimus dorsi or pectoralis major tendons.

choices.text: Teres major and teres minor

questions.text: Rotator interval is between:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supraspinatus and Subscapularis

 

Option C)

 

ROTATOR INTERVAL

 

  • Rotator interval is a triangular portion of shoulder capsule which lies between supraspinatus and subscapularis tendon and coracohumeral ligament passes through it.
  • The rotator interval is an anatomic region in the anterosuperior aspect of the glenohumeral joint that represents a complex interaction of the fibres of the coracohumeral ligament, the superior glenohumeral ligament, the glenohumeral joint capsule, and the supraspinatus and subscapularis tendons. 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Rotator cuff interval is formed between the supraspinatus and subscapularis tendons.

questions.text: A Bennett’s fracture is difficult to maintain in a reduced position mainly because of the pull of the:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abductor pollicis longus

 

Option D)

 

BENNETT’S FRACTURE

 

  • An intra articular fracture through the base of the first metacarpal in which the shaft is laterally dislocated by the unopposed pull of the abductor pollicis longus.
  • The medial projection of the thumb metacarpal base on which the volar oblique ligament attaches remains in place.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A Bennett’s fracture is difficult to reduce or maintain in a reduced position because of the proximal and radial pull of the abductor pollicis longus muscle.

choices.text: Posterior cord of brachial plexus

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is injured in inferior dislocation of shoulder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Axillary nerve

 

Option B)

 

INFERIOR SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Potentially serious consequences, e.g., neurovascular damage is quite common.
  • Axillary nerve is injured.

 

Remember: Most common nerve involved in any (shoulder dislocation) is axillary nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

In inferior dislocation of shoulder, axillary nerve is injured.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy has a history of recurrent dislocation of the right shoulder. On examination, the orthopedician puts the patient in the supine position and abducts his arm to 90° with the bed as the fulcrum and then externally rotates it but the boy does not allow the test to be performed. The test done by the orthopedician is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apprehension test

 

Option A)

 

APPREHENSION TEST

 

  • In General, these maneuvers mimic the positioning of subluxation or dislocation. 
  • Application of anteriorly directed force to the humeral head from the back or abduction and external rotation of arm results in patient’s apprehension that the joint will dislocate and the patient does not allow the test to be performed.

 

 

  • Variations include:
    • Fulcrum test
    • Crank test
    • Surprise test (most accurate)
    • Jobe’s relocation test

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sulcus test. The sulcus test is used to assess the glenohumeral joint for inferior instability, due to laxity of the superior glenohumeral ligament and coracohumeral ligament. The patient sits upright with their shoulder in neutral. The examiner then pulls the distal part of the humerus in a caudal direction. The test is considered positive when the subacromial space is more than 1cm.

 

 

Option C. Dugas test. With the patient seated, instruct him to touch the opposite shoulder and bring the elbow to the chest wall. The test is positive if the patient experiences inability to touch the opposite shoulder because of pain. This indicates anterior dislocation of the humeral head.
 

 

Option D. McMurray’s test. McMurray's test is used to determine the presence of a meniscal tear within the knee. Patient Position is supine lying with knee completely flexed. The examiner holds the knee with one hand and palpates the joint line. The other hand holds the sole of the foot, supporting the limb and provides the required movement through range. From a position of maximal flexion, extend the knee with internal rotation (IR) of the tibia and apply a VARUS stress, then return to maximal flexion and extend the knee with external rotation (ER) of the tibia and apply a VALGUS stress. IR of the tibia + Varus stress = lateral meniscus injury; ER of the tibia + Valgus stress = medial meniscus injury.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described test in the question is the apprehension test of the shoulder done to test the anterior shoulder instability, where the patient apprehends from the movement due to the fear of pain.

questions.text: Most common bone to fracture in body is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clavicle

 

Option A)

 

  • Clavicle is the most common fractured bone (overall) in adults and during birth.
  • Clavicle is the 4th common fractured bone in children after distal radius and ulna; hand injuries; elbow injuries in order of priority.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Clavicle is the most common bone to be fractured overall in adults and during birth.
  • Other bones commonly fractured are distal radius, proximal femur, proximal humerus and the metacarpal bones.

questions.text: Velpeau bandage, Sling and Swathe splint are used in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acromioclavicular dislocation

 

Option C)

 

TREATMENT OF ACROMIOCLAVICULAR DISLOCATION

 

  • Velpeau bandage (dressing) is used in acromioclavicular dislocation, fracture clavicle and shoulder dislocation but it is most effective in acromioclavicular dislocation as it pushes lateral end of shoulder downwards and arm upwards, and thus helps maintaining reduction.

  • This treatment method is used in the conservative treatment of the type 1, 2 and 3 of the acromioclavicular dislocation.
  • Rockwood classification of AC joint dislocation:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Shoulder dislocation. Conservative management usually involves a period of rest, immobilisation of the arm in a sling, for three to six weeks, followed by a supervised physiotherapy and rehabilitation programme. 

 

Option B. Fracture scapula. Most scapular fractures are managed effectively with closed treatment and medical management. In minimally displaced fractures, management is with short-term immobilization in a sling and swath. Patients should progress as quickly as possible to begin early range of motion exercises to prevent frozen shoulder as tolerated. 

 

Option D. Fracture clavicle. The most common method of conservative management of the clavicle fracture is the use of a sling or ’figure-of-eight’ bandage, or a combination of these two methods.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Velpeau bandage, sling, and swathe splint are used for the management of the acromioclavicular joint dislocation.

choices.text: Anterior interosseous nerve
Median nerve
Ulnar nerve

questions.text: Nerve injured in fracture of medial epicondyle of humerus is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve

 

Option C)

 

MEDIAL EPICONDYLE FRACTURE

 

  • Ulnar nerve lies in very close proximity to the medial epicondyle in cubital tunnel.
  • Fracture of the medial epicondyle can potentially injure or compress the ulnar nerve due to its proximity to this bony prominence.
  • So, it is the most commonly injured nerve in the fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior interosseous nerve. This nerve can be injured in case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

 

Option B. Median nerve. This nerve can also get damaged in supracondylar humerus fractures.

 

Option D. Radial nerve. This nerve is injured in the humerus shaft fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The nerve most commonly injured in the fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus is the ulnar nerve.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are indication of surgical management of fracture shaft humerus?

 

  1. Fracture in elderly
  2. Radial nerve involvement after manipulation
  3. Pathological fractures
  4. Vascular injury
  5. Multiple fractures
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 4, 5

 

Option A)

 

INDICATION FOR SURGERY OF HUMERUS SHAFT FRACTURE

 

 

Explanation:

 

1. Fracture in elderly. Fractures of the humeral shaft in elderly individuals may present challenges due to factors such as osteoporosis, decreased bone density, and associated medical conditions. In some cases, especially if the fracture is displaced or unstable, surgical intervention may be necessary to achieve proper alignment and stabilization for optimal healing.

 

2. Radial nerve involvement after manipulation. The radial nerve travels along the humerus, and fractures of the humeral shaft can potentially injure or compress the radial nerve. If there is evidence of radial nerve involvement, such as weakness or sensory deficits in the distribution of the nerve, surgical exploration and intervention may be required to address the nerve injury, restore function, and prevent long-term disability.

 

â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹3. Pathological fractures. Pathological fractures occur as a result of underlying bone pathology, such as tumors or metastatic lesions. These fractures can be associated with significant instability and may not heal properly with conservative management alone. Surgical stabilization of the fracture can help provide structural support, relieve pain, and prevent further complications associated with the underlying pathology.

 

â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹4. Vascular injury. While vascular injury is not a direct indication for surgical management of a fracture shaft of the humerus, it is a serious complication that may require surgical intervention. Fractures associated with vascular injury may result in compromised blood flow to the arm, leading to ischemia and tissue damage. Surgical exploration and repair of the vascular injury may be necessary to restore blood flow and prevent complications such as compartment syndrome or limb loss.

 

â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹5. Multiple fractures. Fractures of the humeral shaft can occur in isolation or in combination with other fractures, especially in cases of high-energy trauma. Multiple fractures increase the complexity of management and may require surgical intervention to address each fracture adequately. Surgery can help stabilize the fractures, facilitate healing, and restore function to the affected limb.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Indications for surgical management of a fracture shaft of the humerus include fractures in elderly individuals, radial nerve involvement after manipulation, pathological fractures, vascular injury, and multiple fractures.
  • Each case should be carefully evaluated, and the decision for surgical intervention should be made based on factors such as the severity of the fracture, associated injuries, patient's overall health, and functional goals.
  • A nerve palsy after a closed manipulation is an indication for exploration + ORIF.
  • A pathological fracture requires ORIF + Grafting + External fixation.

questions.text: In posterior compartment syndrome, which passive move­ment causes pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toe dorsiflexion

 

Option C)

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • Toe dorsiflexion as passive stretch should be performed at distal most joint of the extremity.
  • This passive movement causes pain or aggravates the pain in the compartment syndrome.
  • This is seen as the 1st sign, suggesting of compartment syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the posterior compartment syndrome, the passive toe dorsiflexion is a provocative movement as it increases the pain.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 88

questions.text: Most common site of myositis ossificans is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elbow

 

Option B)

 

SITES OF MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS

 

  • Myositis Ossificans is seen in Elbow (MC) followed by hip joint.
  • In elbow, Myositis is seen more commonly anteriorly than posteriorly.
  • Massage to the elbow and vigorous passive stretching to restore movements is aggravating factor.
  • It occurs in muscles which are vulnerable to heavy loads, such as brachialis (commonest), biceps.
  • Surgical trauma specially total hip replacement, is precipitating factor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Knee. It is rarely found in the knee. It may occur following quadriceps contusion.

 

Option C. Shoulder. It is rarely involved in the heterotopic ossification or myositis ossificans.

 

Option D. Wrist. Pseudomalignant or non-traumatic myositis ossificans can sometimes involve hand and wrist but not the traumatic myositis ossificans.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common sites of development of myositis ossificans is the elbow followed by the hip joint.

questions.text: Nerve commonly damaged in fracture shaft humerus is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial nerve

 

Option B)

 

NERVE DAMAGE IN HUMERUS SHAFT FRACTURE

 

  • Injury to the radial nerve is the most common association of humerus shaft fracture.
  • It occurs in 2-5% cases.
  • Radial nerve injuries usually occur in fractures affecting a 10–15cm path where the radial nerve courses along the periosteum of the middle and middle-distal humerus.
  • As the nerve has very little mobility in this area, but has only minimal protection, it is highly susceptible to injury.
  • Transverse and spiral fractures are most likely to result in palsy.
  • These are followed by displaced high-energy fracture patterns.
  • In cases of displacement, stretching is a common source of injury.
  • As stretches as short as 1–2mm can cause damage, virtually any tension is problematic.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Axillary nerve. Axillary nerve is damaged most commonly in surgical neck of humerus fractures.

 

Option C. Ulnar nerve. Injury to the ulnar nerve following humerus shaft fracture is a very rare entity because the ulnar nerve is well protected from the bone by muscle and soft tissue, and thus remains unaffected in these fractures.

 

Option D. Median nerve. Median nerve injury due to humerus shaft fracture is also seen infrequently.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly injured nerve in the fracture of shaft of the humerus is the radial nerve.

questions.text: Hanging cast is used in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fracture humerus

 

Option D)

 

HUMERUS SHAFT FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • The most common cause of delayed union or non-union is distraction at fracture site due to gravity and weight of plaster.
  • A spiral fracture of the distal third of the humerus is called a Holstein-Lewis fracture.
  • It is frequently associated with radial nerve palsy.
  • Coaptation splint/Hanging cast is used for non-operative management.
  • Plating for treatment (usually) if surgery indicated.
  • The hanging cast must be light weight and must extend from at least 1 inch proximal to the fracture site to wrist, with elbow at right angle & forearm in neutral rotation.
  • The arm must lie dependent to provide a traction force.  
  • The patient must sleep erect or semierect to avoid supporting elbow when seated.
  • Erect position is maintained during the day.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fracture femur. In children, the spica cast is applied while in adults, the fracture is immobilized in a splint or a cast.

 

Option B. Fracture radius. A short arm gutter splint is recommended for initial immobilization for few days to settle the swelling. Once swelling reduces, a cast is applied.

 

Option C. Fracture tibia. A long leg cast is applied for 6 weeks followed by a short leg cast and then an aircast boot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hanging cast is used to treat the fracture of the humerus shaft.

choices.text: Overriding of fracture ends

questions.text: The most important cause of non-union of fracture of humeral shaft is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Distraction at fracture site

 

Option D)

 

NON-UNION FRACTURE OF HUMERUS SHAFT

 

  • Non-unions may be of two types: hypertrophic non-union (have viable ends and exuberant callus formation) and atrophic non-union (non-viable bone ends and no callus formation).
  • As a generalization, those non-unions with better blood supply and some degree of micromotion at fracture site develop more callus, while those with either no motion, excess motion, or distraction and a less rich blood supply produce less callus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Comminuted fracture. Comminuted fractures can pose challenges to healing, they do not necessarily represent the most important cause of non-union.

 

Option B. Compound (open) fracture. These fractures are at higher risk of infection, which can hinder healing. However, infection is not the most important cause of non-union in humeral shaft fractures.

 

Option C. Overriding fracture ends. Overriding occurs when the fractured ends of the bone are displaced and do not align properly. Misalignment can interfere with the healing process, but it is not necessarily the primary cause of non-union.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Distraction can prevent the fractured ends from coming into close contact, which is essential for the formation of callus and subsequent healing.
  • Therefore, distraction at the fracture site is a critical factor contributing to non-union in humeral shaft fractures.

questions.text: Deformity with decreased carrying angle is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cubitus varus

 

Option A)

 

CARRYING ANGLE

 

  • Angle between long axis of arm and forearm is called the carrying angle.
  • This angle is more in females because of lower level of trochlea in female.
  • Normal value is 5–15°.
  • Cubitus Varus is reduced carrying angle and cubitus valgus is increased carrying angle.
  • Varus means that the distal part is towards midline and valgus means distal part is away from midline.

 

 

Note: Malunion around elbow causes Varus = cubitus (elbow) varus.

 

Non-union around elbow causes valgus = cubitus valgus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Manus varus. This involves congenital aplasia of the radius. The forerarm appears shortened.

 

Option C. Cubitus valgus. This is the increased carrying angle of the elbow.

 

Option D. Manus valgus. It is the radial club hand deformity caused due to pathological destruction of the distal radius following infection, trauma, or tumor, leading to radial shortening, ulnar lengthening and angulation, distal radioulnar joint dislocation, and radial deviation of the wrist.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Deformity with decreased carrying angle is cubitus varus.

questions.text: Cubitus valgus develops as complication of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jupiter fracture

 

Option A)

 

JUPITER FRACTURE

 

  • Jupiter classification is for fractures of lower end humerus.

 

 

 

  • Lateral Column fractures cause Cubitus valgus and medial column fractures can cause cubitus varus in case of complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Smith fracture. The malunion of this fracture leads to cubitus varus deformity.

 

Option C. Malgaigne fracture. The Malgaigne fracture develops as a fracture of both pubic rami and the posterior region of the sacroiliac complex. It does not have any relation with cubitus deformity seen at the elbow.

 

Option D. Straddle fracture. Straddle fracture of the pelvis (fracture of both superior and inferior pubic rami) is considered an unstable injury. This fracture has no relation with the cubitus deformity of the elbow.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Cubitus valgus develops as a complication Jupiter fracture.

questions.text: First to appear amongst the ossification centres about the elbow is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capitellum

 

Option D)

 

ELBOW ANATOMY

 

  • Capitellum is the first ossification centre about the elbow to appear.
  • It appears around 2 years of age.
  • The mnemonic “CRITOE” is helpful in remembering the progression of the radiographic appearance of ossification centre about the elbow in children:
    • C: Capitellum – 2 years
    • R: Radius head – 4 years
    • I: Internal (medial) epicondyle – 6 years
    • T: Trochlea – 8 years
    • O: Olecranon – 10 years
    • E: External (Lateral) epicondyle – 12 years

 

 

Order of fusion with humerus

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Radial head. The radial head ossifies at around age 3-4 years.

 

Option B. Olecranon. Olecranon ossifies by the age of 6-11 years.

 

Option C. Lateral epicondyle. This area of the bone ossifies by the age of 8-13 years.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Capitellum is the first bone to appear among the ossification centres about the elbow.

questions.text: Three bony point relationship is maintained in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supracondylar fracture humerus

 

Option A)

 

THREE-POINT BONY LANDMARKS IN ELBOW

 

  • The tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and the olecranon.
  • Form Isosceles triangle – In Elbow flexion of 90 degree.
  • Lie transversely in straight line – Elbow Extension.

 

 

  • Three-point bony relationship is not disturbed in fracture supracondylar humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dislocation of elbow. The three bony point relationship is disturbed in elbow dislocation, but the intercondylar distance is maintained.

 

Option C. Fracture lateral condyle. The three bony point relationship is disturbed in lateral condyle fracture and the intercondylar distance is increased.

 

Option D. Intercondylar fracture. The three bony point relationship is disturbed in intercondylar fracture and the intercondylar distance is increased.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The three bony point relationship is maintained in the supracondylar humerus fracture because the fracture lies above the bony landmarks that form this relationship.

choices.text: Head of radius, lateral epicondyle, medial epicondyle
Head of radius, lateral epicondyle, olecranon
Olecranon, medial epicondyle, neck of radius
Neck of radius, head of radius, lateral epicondyle

questions.text: Posterolateral anconeus triangle is formed by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head of radius, lateral epicondyle, olecranon

 

Option B)

 

ANCONEUS TRAINGLE

 

  • Radial head, lateral epicondyle and tip of olecranon form a triangle over the posterolateral aspect of elbow joint.
  • This space is occupied by anconeus muscle and so known as anconeus triangle.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The posterolateral anconeus triangle is formed by the head of radius, lateral epicondyle and the olecranon.

choices.text: Superficial branch of ulnar nerve

questions.text: A patient of supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex interphalangeal joint of the thumb. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior Interosseous Nerve

 

Option C)

 

COMPLICATIONS OF FRACTURE SUPRACONDYLAR HUMERUS

 

  • Malunion: Most Common Complication
  • Posteromedially displaced fracture tend to develop Cubitus varus (gun stock deformity).
     

 

  • Vascular injury: brachial artery
  • Nerve injury: anterior interosseous nerve > median nerve > radial nerve > ulnar nerve – neuropraxia

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Median nerve. This is the second commonly involved nerve in the supracondylar humerus fracture after anterior interosseous nerve.

 

Option B. Superficial branch of ulnar nerve. It is less commonly involved nerve in this injury.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Anterior interosseous nerve controls the flexion of the thumb through the flexor pollicis longus muscle.
  • Since the question mentions the inability to flex the IP joint of the thumb after the supracondylar humerus fracture, thus the nerve involved in this case scenario is the anterior interosseous nerve.

choices.text: Medial closing wedge osteotomy
Lateral closing wedge osteotomy
Medial opening wedge osteotomy

questions.text: Preferred treatment of cubitus varus is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral closing wedge osteotomy

 

Option B)

 

CUBITUS VARUS

 

  • Postero-medially displaced supracondylar fracture tends to develop Cubitus varus (gun stock deformity).

 

 

  • Cubitus varus deformity in fracture supracondylar humerus is managed by French/modified French osteotomy i.e., lateral closing wedge osteotomy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Medial closing wedge osteotomy. This procedure is commonly used to correct angular deformities or malalignments where the affected bone is angled too much towards the medial side. Conditions such as genu valgum or tibial vara (Blount's disease) can be treated with medial closing wedge osteotomy.

 

Option C. Medial opening wedge osteotomy. Medial opening wedge osteotomy is typically utilized to address angular deformities or malalignments where the affected bone is angled too much towards the lateral side. Conditions such as genu varum can be treated with this procedure.

 

Option D. Lateral opening wedge osteotomy. Lateral opening wedge osteotomy is employed to correct angular deformities or malalignments where the affected bone is angled too much towards the medial side. This procedure is less common compared to medial opening wedge osteotomy but can be used for genu valgum.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The preferred treatment for cubitus varus is lateral closing wedge osteotomy, also known as French or Modified osteotomy.

choices.text: Pain or decreased range of motion on both active and passive movement
Pain on active movement but not on passive movement

questions.text: A patient presents to you with musculoskeletal complaints. The main concern is to differentiate articular versus non articular origin of pain. Which of the following feature is suggestive of non-articular origin of pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on active movement but not on passive movement

 

Option D)

 

NON-ARTICULAR VS ARTICULAR ORIGIN OF PAIN

 

  • Articular disorders are characterized by internal/deep joint pain that is exacerbated by active and passive motion and by reduced range of motion.
  • Extraarticular disorders are associated with joint pain with active motion rather than passive motion and in addition, range of motion often is preserved.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pain or decreased range of motion on both active and passive movement. In the non-articular type of pain, the pain is present on the active movements only. The limitation of movement or decreased movement is there only during the active movement.

 

Option B. Swelling. Swelling may be present in the non-articular origin of pain.

 

Option C. Crepitation. This is usually absent or unrelated.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the non-articular origin of pain, there is pain on the active movement and not on passive movement; the ROM is decreased during the active motion; swelling and crepitus may be present or absent.

choices.text: Lateral condyle humerus fracture

questions.text: A child presents with the following deformity. Most common etiology is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

Option A)

 

COMPLICATIONS OF FRACTURE SUPRACONDYLAR HUMERUS

 

  • Malunion – Most Common Complication.
  • Postero-medially displaced fracture tends to develop Cubitus varus (gun stock deformity).

 

 

  • Cubitus varus deformity in fracture supracondylar humerus is managed by French/modified French osteotomy (lateral closing wedge osteotomy).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lateral condyle humerus fracture. Non-union of this fracture can lead to cubitus valgus deformity in children.

 

Option C. Radial head dislocation. Long-term dislocations often result in valgus deformity of the elbow.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given deformity in the question is the gun stock or cubitus varus deformity which is seen as a complication of malunion of supracondylar humerus fracture.

choices.text: Emergency brachial artery exploration
Closed reduction of fracture and look for reappearance of pulse
Closed reduction, above elbow slab plaster and observe
Open reduction and internal fixation of fracture

questions.text: In Supracondylar fracture of humerus in children, if the radial pulse is absent, what is next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed reduction of fracture and look for reappearance of pulse

 

Option B)

 

FRACTURE SUPRACONDYLAR HUMERUS

 

  • Most common fracture associated with vascular injury.
  • Most common fracture to involve brachial artery (10% cases).
  • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemia and compartment syndrome in children.
  • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemic contracture.
  • Non-union is unknown.
  • Treatment for supracondylar fracture humerus in children:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Emergency brachial artery exploration. This step is done when the pulse does not return even after reduction of the fracture.

 

Option C. Closed reduction, above elbow slab plaster, and observe. This option is chosen when the absence of the radial pulse is not immediately concerning for arterial injury, and there is a need to assess the response to conservative management before considering more invasive interventions.

 

Option D. Open reduction and internal fixation of the fracture. This option is typically reserved for cases where closed reduction is not successful, or there are complications such as neurovascular compromise requiring surgical intervention. While open reduction and internal fixation may be necessary in some cases, it is usually not the initial step when the radial pulse is absent unless there are other indications for surgery.

 

Educational objective:
 

  • In case of an absent radial pulse in a child with supracondylar humerus fracture, the best line of management is the closed reduction of the fracture and observe for the reappearance of the pulse.

questions.text: All the following are complications of supracondylar fracture of humerus in children, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-union

 

Option D)

 

COMPLICATIONS OF FRACTURE SUPRACONDYLAR HUMERUS

 

1. Malunion: Most Common Complication

  • Postero-medially displaced fracture tends to develop Cubitus varus (gun stock deformity).
  • Cubitus varus deformity in fracture supracondylar humerus is managed by French/modified French osteotomy (lateral closing wedge osteotomy).
  • Bauman’s Angle: Angle between the physis and long axis of humerus – normal value = 75–90 degrees – Increased in cubitus varus

 

 

2. Vascular (brachial artery) injury

 

3. Nerve injury (anterior interosseous nerve > median nerve > radial nerve >ulnar nerve): These are usually neuropraxia, hence transient.

 

 

4. Volkmann's ischemia and compartment syndrome

 

5. Elbow stiffness

 

6. Myositis ossificans

 

7. Avascular necrosis of trochlea (rare)

 

8. Tardy ulnar nerve palsy

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Compartment syndrome, Option B. Myositis ossificans, and Option C. Malunion are the common complications seen following supracondylar humerus fracture in children.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Out of the given options, non-union is not a complication of supracondylar humerus fracture in children.
  • Instead malunion is the most common complication which leads to cubitus varus deformity.

choices.text: Coronoid process posterior to humerus
Coronoid process anterior to humerus
Coronoid process below humerus

questions.text: What is seen on X-ray with posterior elbow dislocation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coronoid process posterior to humerus

 

Option A)

 

X-RAY OF POSTERIOR ELBOW DISLOCATION

 

  • The most common dislocation in elbow is posterior or posterolateral and is usually the result of a fall with forearm supinated and the elbow either extended or partially flexed.
  • Simple dislocations of the elbow result in injuries of the medial and lateral collateral ligament complexes without bony injury.
  • Complex dislocations are those associated with fractures about the elbow.
  • Associated soft tissue injuries may involve the brachial artery, ulnar nerve (most commonly), median and radial nerve
  • In the x-ray, the coronoid process is seen posterior to humerus.

 

 

  • Most prominent part is olecranon in dislocated elbow.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the x-ray of a posterior dislocation of the elbow, the coronoid process is seen posterior to the humerus.

questions.text: Microcirculation blockade is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Compartment syndrome

 

Option C)

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In compartment syndrome, the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intra-compartmental pressure is capillary compression > venous compression > arterial compression.
  • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
  • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
  • Microcirculation blockade refers to the impairment or obstruction of blood flow in the small blood vessels (microvessels) within tissues.
  • Compartment syndrome occurs when increased pressure within a closed muscle compartment impairs blood flow to the muscles and nerves within that compartment.
  • This increased pressure can lead to microcirculation blockade, causing tissue ischemia, nerve damage, and potentially severe complications if left untreated.
  • Compartment syndrome is often considered a surgical emergency requiring prompt intervention to relieve the pressure and restore blood flow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sudeck’s deformity. Also known as complex regional pain syndrome, it is a chronic pain condition that typically affects an arm, leg, hand, or foot after an injury. It is characterized by severe pain, swelling, changes in skin colour and temperature, and sometimes motor dysfunction. While vascular changes can occur in Sudeck's dystrophy, microcirculation blockade is not a primary feature of this condition.

 

Option B. Myositis ossificans. Myositis ossificans is a condition where bone tissue forms within muscle tissue, usually as a result of injury or trauma. It can cause pain, swelling, and restricted movement. While myositis ossificans can lead to local tissue changes, it is not primarily associated with microcirculation blockade.

 

Educational objective:

 

Microcirculation blockade is a characteristic feature of the compartment syndrome.

choices.text: Old unreduced dislocation of elbow
Non-union lateral condylar humerus fracture
Malunited intercondylar fracture of humerus
Malunited supracondylar fracture of humerus

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presenting with a cubitus varus deformity and a history of trauma 3 months back. On clinical examination, the 3 bony point relationship of the elbow was preserved. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Malunited supracondylar fracture of humerus

 

Option D)

 

POST-TRAUMATIC CUBITUS VARUS DEFORMITY

 

  • The most common cause of the cubitus varus deformity following a trauma in children is the malunion of the supracondylar humerus fracture.
  • The gunstock/cubitus varus deformity is formed by the posteromedial displacement of the fracture.

 

 

  • The three-point bony relationship in the elbow is formed by the tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and the olecranon.
  • They form an isosceles triangle when the elbow is flexed to 90â° and lies transversely in a straight line when the elbow is extended.

 

 

  • This three-point relationship is not disturbed in the supracondylar humerus fracture because the fracture occurs above the level of the bony landmarks involved.
  • Thus, the described cubitus varus with preserved three-point bony relationship suggests the diagnosis of malunited supracondylar fracture.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Old unreduced dislocation of elbow. This leads to retraction of triceps muscles and collateral ligaments. Patients presents with a deformed, stiff and painful elbow with difficulty to perform activities of daily living. The clinical picture looks quite similar to malunited supracondylar fracture of the elbow. On presentation, elbow is deformed either in extension or minimal flexion with a limited range of movements. The relationship of three bony point on the posterior aspect of elbow is altered with a prominent olecranon tip at the apex of a scalene upright triangle attached to a shortened and wasted triceps muscle.

 

Option B. Non-union lateral condylar humerus fracture. If left untreated, non-union can lead to pain, instability and cubitus valgus deformity with progressive ulnar nerve palsy. The three-point bony relation is disturbed, with the widening of intercondylar distance and with the migration of lateral epicondyle proximally.

 

Option C. Malunited intercondylar fracture of humerus. This also presents with a cubitus valgus deformity and an altered three-point bony relationship with increased intercondylar distance.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Cubitus varus deformity with maintained three bony point relationship after 3 months of injury suggests the diagnosis of malunited supracondylar fracture humerus.â€‹

choices.text: Patient with delayed capillary refill time in fingers of the involved limb
Having Intra-articular extension of the fracture
With Abrasion over the fracture of more than 10 cm
Having Weakness of wrist extensors

questions.text: You are an intern in a busy casualty. A patient comes with upper limb fracture. According to priority to be given, which of these should be reviewed urgently by an Orthopedic resident?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patient with delayed capillary refill time in fingers of the involved limb

 

Option A)

 

VASCULAR INJURY WITH UPPER LIMB FRACTURE

 

  • Vascular injury > Neurological.
  • Delayed capillary refill time indicates poor blood circulation to the fingers, which can be a sign of compromised blood flow due to factors such as vascular injury or compartment syndrome.
  • This is a concerning sign that warrants urgent evaluation by an orthopedic resident to assess and address the vascular status of the limb.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Having intra-articular extension of the fracture. Intra-articular extension means that the fracture extends into a joint. Intra-articular fractures can lead to joint instability, cartilage damage, and potential long-term joint dysfunction if not managed appropriately. While this is significant, it may not be as immediately urgent as compromised blood flow.

 

Option C. With abrasion over the fracture of more than 10 cm. An abrasion over the fracture site indicates soft tissue damage but does not necessarily indicate an immediate threat to the patient's health or limb function. While it may require attention, it is typically not as urgent as issues related to vascular compromise or intra-articular extension.

 

Option D. Having weakness of wrist extensors. Weakness of wrist extensors may indicate nerve injury or dysfunction, such as radial nerve injury. While nerve injuries are important to assess and manage, they generally do not pose an immediate threat to life or limb compared to vascular compromise.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In a patient presenting with an upper limb fracture in the emergency, the vascular injury should be checked on priority.
  • This can be seen if the patient has a delayed capillary refill time in the fingers of the involved limb.

questions.text: Supracondylar fracture is usually caused by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperextension injury

 

Option D)

 

SUPRACONDYLAR FRACTURE

 

  • Supracondylar fracture (most common extension type) occurs due to hyperextension injury, usually due to fall on outstretched hand.
  • Most common type of distal fragment displacement in extension type fracture supracondylar humerus is “Posteromedial displacement with internal rotation”.
  • Flexion type of supracondylar fracture occurs due to fall directly on elbow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyperflexion injury, Option B. Axial rotation injury, and Option C. Extension injury are commonly seen mechanisms of injury in the elbow dislocation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The supracondylar humerus fracture is usually caused by the hyperextension injury of the elbow during fall on an outstretched hand.

choices.text: Usually seen at 6-10 years of age
Results in Gun stock deformity
Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding fractures of lateral condyle of humerus except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Results in Gun stock deformity

 

Option B)

 

FRACTURE LATERAL CONDYLE HUMERUS

 

  • This is a transphyseal intra-articular injury usually involving immature skeleton of children and adolescent.
  • The lateral condylar (or capitellar) epiphysis begins to ossify during the first year of life and fuses with shaft at 12–16 years.
  • Between these ages, it may be sheared off or avulsed by forceful traction.
  • The maximum chances of injury is between 5–15 years.
  • They are the most common distal humeral epiphyseal fractures.
  • Mechanism of Fracture Lateral Condyle Humerus:
    • Fall on outstretched arm with Varus stress (mostly) that “Pulls off” (avulses) lateral condyle or Valgus force (rarely) in which radial head directly pushes off the lateral condyle.
  • Complications:
    1. Non-union is most frequent problematic complication.
      • The most common sequela of non-union with displacement is the development of progressive cubitus valgus deformity.
      • Treatment of cubitus valgus – Milch Osteotomy.
    2. Cubitus varus/lateral spur formation is the reported complication following lateral condyle fracture subsequent to malunion of fractures after surgical intervention.
      • Treatment of cubitus varus – Modified French Osteotomy.
      • Remember that cubitus valgus is much more common than true cubitus varus in fracture lateral condyle humerus, because non-union is more common than malunion in fracture lateral body humerus.
    3. Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a late complication of progressive cubitus valgus > cubitus varus deformity occurring in lateral condylar fractures.
    4. Growth (physeal) arrest, avascular necrosis and fishtail deformity are other rare complications.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lateral condyle humerus fractures are mostly seen in the age group of 6-10 years because by this age, the lateral condyle fuses with the shaft of the humerus.
  • The gunstock deformity or cubitus varus is less commonly seen in this fracture. It is observed after the malunion of the fracture from the surgical intervention.
  • The most commonly seen deformity is the cubitus valgus deformity due to the non-union with displacement of the fracture fragments. This deformity is progressive.
  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a late complication and is progressive.

questions.text: A child following fall on outstretched arm, presented with tenderness and crepitus over lateral condyle humerus along with instability of elbow. The condition of the child can cause which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

COMPLICATIONS ASSOCIATED WITH FRACTURE LATERAL CONDYLE HUMERUS

 

  1. Non-union is most frequent problematic complication.
    • The most common sequela of non-union with displacement is the development of progressive cubitus valgus deformity.
    • Treatment of cubitus valgus – Milch Osteotomy.
  2. Cubitus varus/lateral spur formation is the reported complication following lateral condyle fracture subsequent to malunion of fractures after surgical intervention.
    • Treatment of cubitus varus - Modified French Osteotomy.
    • Remember that cubitus valgus is much more common than true cubitus varus in fracture lateral condyle humerus, because non-union is more common than malunion in fracture lateral body humerus.
  3. Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a late complication of progressive cubitus valgus > cubitus varus deformity occurring in lateral condylar fractures.
  4. Growth (physeal) arrest, avascular necrosis and fishtail deformity are other rare complications.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The fall on an outstretched arm, tenderness and crepitus over the lateral condyle of humerus and an unstable elbow are suggestive of lateral condyle humerus fracture.
  • This fracture is associated with complications like non-union (most common – leading to cubitus valgus), malunion (leading to cubitus varus), and ulnar nerve palsy (late and progressive).

questions.text: Most common complication of lateral condyle humerus fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-union

 

Option B)

 

COMPLICATIONS ASSOCIATED WITH FRACTURE LATERAL CONDYLE HUMERUS

 

  1. Non-union is most frequent problematic complication.
    • The most common sequela of non-union with displacement is the development of progressive cubitus valgus deformity.
    • Treatment of cubitus valgus – Milch Osteotomy.
  2. Cubitus varus/lateral spur formation is the reported complication following lateral condyle fracture subsequent to malunion of fractures after surgical intervention.
    • Treatment of cubitus varus - Modified French Osteotomy.
    • Remember that cubitus valgus is much more common than true cubitus varus in fracture lateral condyle humerus, because non-union is more common than malunion in fracture lateral body humerus.
  3. Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a late complication of progressive cubitus valgus > cubitus varus deformity occurring in lateral condylar fractures.
  4. Growth (physeal) arrest, avascular necrosis and fishtail deformity are other rare complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Malunion. This is seen mostly after the surgical intervention.

 

Option C. Volkmann’s ischemic contracture. This is classically associated with supracondylar humerus fracture.

 

Option D. Median nerve injury. This is also associated commonly with the supracondylar humerus fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common complication of the fracture lateral condyle humerus is the non-union and displacement of the fractured fragments.

choices.text: Fracture of both bones of forearm
Epiphyseal separation of tibia
Intercondylar fracture of femur
Lateral condyle fracture of humerus

questions.text: Which fracture requires open reduction in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral condyle fracture of humerus

 

Option D)

 

LATERAL CONDYLE HUMERUS FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Results are unsatisfactory after closed treatment, so open reduction and internal fixation with K-wires/screws is necessary, hence this fracture is termed as fracture of necessity.
  • Fractures of necessity (requiring surgery):
  • Galeazzi fracture dislocation (Classical Example)
  • Lateral condyle fracture humerus
  • Displaced fracture olecranon and patella
  • Fracture neck femur
  • Monteggia fracture in adults
  • Articular fractures

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fracture of both bones of forearm. In children, these fractures are mostly treated with closed reduction and immobilization. Open reduction is indicated in children > 13 years who are nearing skeletal maturity.

 

Option B. Epiphyseal separation of tibia. In many cases, conservative management is done in epiphyseal separation of tibia. This involves immobilization of the affected limb in a cast or a splint and avoid weight bearing on the affected limb. Open reduction is indicated if the there is significant displacement of the fragments or if the blood supply to the growth plate is compromised.

 

Option C. Intercondylar fracture of femur. In some cases, particularly for minimally displaced or stable fractures, nonsurgical treatment may be appropriate. This typically involves immobilizing the affected limb with a cast or brace and to avoid weight-bearing activities. If the intercondylar femur fracture is displaced or unstable, surgical intervention may be necessary.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The lateral condyle fracture of humerus is considered as a fracture of necessity which needs to be treated with open reduction and internal fixation because the closed treatment gives unsatisfactory results.

choices.text: Medial condyle fracture humerus
Lateral condyle fracture humerus

questions.text: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral condyle fracture humerus

 

Option B)

 

TARDY ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy as a late complication of fracture lateral condyle physis is well known, especially after the development of cubitus valgus and less commonly after cubitus varus.
  • The symptoms are usually gradual in onset and may appear years after injury.
  • Motor loss occur first, with sensory changes developing later.
  • Anterior transposition of ulnar nerve is most commonly used procedure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Medial condyle fracture humerus. In this fracture, the medial nerve is compressed between the apophysis and the distal humerus.

 

Option C. Supracondylar fracture humerus. The most commonly affected nerve is the anterior interosseous nerve in the supracondylar humerus fracture.

 

Option D. Fracture shaft of humerus. In this, the radial nerve is most commonly involved.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen in lateral condyle humerus fracture.

questions.text: Earliest sign of compartment syndrome of leg is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on Passive stretch

 

Option D)

 

CLINICAL FEATURES OF COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/ any injury (1st symptom).
  • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
  • In compartment syndrome, the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intra-compartmental pressure is: Capillary compression > Venous compression > Arterial compression.
  • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
  • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments.
  • Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > Flexor Pollicis Longus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tingling or numbness. Paresthesia, tingling or numbness occur in the late stages.

 

Option D. Pulselessness. It is also the late feature. Presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.  

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The first sign of compartment syndrome is the pain and resistance to the passive stretch of the distal-most joint of the extremity.

choices.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast
Decreased response to analgesia
Change in colour of fingers

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased response to analgesia

 

Option B)

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME – TIGHT CAST, THINK OF COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndromes, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other Causes:
  1. Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
  2. Exercise: Exercise may increase intra compartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
  • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/ any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
  • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
  • The pain is unrelieved with opioid analgesia.
  • In compartment syndrome, the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intra-compartmental pressure is: Capillary compression > Venous compression > Arterial compression.
  • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
  • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis. Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments.
  • Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > Flexor Pollicis Longus.
  • Treatment:
  • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
  • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure upto 85%.
  • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.
  • The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Check radial pulse by displacing the cast. Pulselessness is the late feature to appear in compartment syndrome. It is not a reliable indicator for the presence of the condition.
