Option C. Change in colour of fingers. This can occur due to vascular insufficiency but is an uncommon entity.

 

Option D. Change in odor. This is not usually observed.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.

choices.text: Fracture of proximal tibia
Fracture of femur shaft

questions.text: Compartment syndrome is commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture of proximal tibia

 

Option A)

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndromes, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other Causes are:
  1. Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
  2. Exercise: Exercise may increase intra-compartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fracture shaft humerus. The risk of compartment syndrome in humeral shaft fractures is relatively lower compared to other fractures.

 

Option D. Fracture distal end radius. Fractures of the distal end of the radius typically do not lead to compartment syndrome unless there are associated injuries or complications such as significant soft tissue damage, extensive swelling, or vascular compromise.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The proximal tibia fracture is commonly associated with compartment syndrome.

questions.text: In Fasciotomy, all of the following are cut except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muscles

 

Option D)

 

FASCIOTOMY

 

  • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.
  • The general indications for fasciotomy are Impending tissue ischemia or when the tissue pressure reaches 30 mm Hg or the difference between diastolic blood pressure and compartment pressure is less than 30 mm of Hg (normal compartment pressure is 8–10 mm of Hg and pressure at calf during walking is 200–300 mm of Hg).
  • In fasciotomy, various layers of tissue are cut to release the pressure and restore blood flow.
  • However, not all tissues are cut during fasciotomy.
  • Fasciotomy must release skin, superficial fascia and deep fascia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Skin. In fasciotomy, the surgical incision is made through the skin to access deeper layers of tissue, including the fascia and muscles.

 

Option B. Superficial fascia. During fasciotomy, the superficial fascia is often incised along with the skin to access the deeper structures, such as the deep fascia and muscles.

 

Option C. Deep fascia. In fasciotomy, the deep fascia is intentionally cut to release pressure within the affected compartment. By cutting the deep fascia, the surgeon allows for decompression of the compartment and restoration of blood flow to the muscles and other tissues.

 

Option D. Muscles. Muscles are not typically cut during fasciotomy unless there is necrosis or severe damage within the muscle compartment. The primary goal of fasciotomy is to release pressure within the compartment without causing unnecessary damage to the muscles. By cutting the deep fascia, pressure is relieved, allowing the muscles to expand and restoring circulation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In fasciotomy, all tissues are cut except for the muscles.
  • The skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia are incised to relieve pressure within the affected muscle compartment and restore blood flow, while the muscles themselves are preserved whenever possible to maintain function and promote healing.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 86

choices.text: Rupture of Achilles tendon
Gastrocnemius and Soleus muscle tear

questions.text: A case of comminuted fracture of tibia presenting with severe pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot. There is also numbness on the sole of foot. Distal pulses are present. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Compartment Syndrome

 

Option C)

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • Clinical Features:
  • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/ any injury (1st symptom).
  • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
  • Severe pain in the calf on dorsiflexion can be a characteristic symptom of compartment syndrome. Dorsiflexion can exacerbate the pain by further increasing the pressure within the affected compartment.
  • In compartment syndrome the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intra-compartmental pressure is: Capillary compression > Venous compression > Arterial compression.
  • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
  • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
  • The presence of distal pulses indicates that arterial blood flow to the foot is not compromised.
  • While compartment syndrome can lead to decreased blood flow and impaired circulation, distal pulses may still be palpable in the early stages of the condition.
  • However, without prompt intervention, compartment syndrome can progress to compromise arterial blood flow and result in ischemia and tissue damage.
  • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments.
  • Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus>Flexor Pollicis Longus.
  • Numbness or altered sensation in the sole of the foot suggests nerve involvement, which is commonly seen in compartment syndrome due to nerve compression within the affected compartment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rupture of Achilles tendon. Rupture of the Achilles tendon typically presents with sudden, sharp pain in the calf or ankle region. Patients may also report hearing a "pop" or snapping sensation at the time of injury. However, dorsiflexion of the foot usually exacerbates pain in cases of Achilles tendon rupture, rather than alleviating it. Additionally, numbness on the sole of the foot is not a characteristic symptom of Achilles tendon rupture.

 

Option B. Gastrocnemius and Soleus muscle tear. A tear in these muscles can result from sudden, forceful contraction or overstretching, often during activities such as running or jumping. While a tear in the gastrocnemius or soleus muscles can cause pain in the calf, dorsiflexion of the foot typically exacerbates the pain, rather than relieving it. Numbness on the sole of the foot is not a characteristic symptom of muscle tear, and distal pulses are typically unaffected.

 

Option D. Tarsal tunnel syndrome. Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a condition caused by compression of the tibial nerve as it passes through the tarsal tunnel, a narrow space on the inside of the ankle. Symptoms may include pain, burning, tingling, or numbness in the sole of the foot, similar to the symptoms described in the scenario. However, tarsal tunnel syndrome is not typically associated with severe pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot. Additionally, a comminuted fracture of the tibia would not directly lead to compression of the tibial nerve within the tarsal tunnel.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In a comminuted tibial fracture presenting with severe calf pain on foot dorsiflexion and numbness in the sole, with present distal pulses, the diagnosis is of compartment syndrome as pain in the area increases with movement in the syndrome while pulses can be present in the early stage.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 86

choices.text: Flexor digitorum superficialis
Pronator teres
Flexor digitorum profundus

questions.text: ‘Volkmann’s Ischaemic Contracture” mostly involves which muscle in Upper Limb?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flexor digitorum profundus

 

Option C)

 

VOLKMANN’S ISCHAEMIC CONTRACTURE

 

  • If a compartment syndrome is untreated or inadequately treated, compartment pressures continue to increase until irreversible tissue ischemia occurs.
  • This results in the formation of the non-infective ischemic contracture of fascial compartments of the extremity known as Volkmann’s Ischaemic Contracture (VIC).
  • In Volkmann ischemic contracture, earliest changes usually involve the flexor digitorum profundus muscles in the middle third of the forearm followed by flexor pollicis longus.
  • The typical clinical picture of established Volkmann contracture includes elbow flexion, forearm pronation, wrist flexion, thumb adduction, metacarpophalangeal joint extension, and finger flexion.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flexor digitorum superficialis, Option B. Pronator teres, and Option D. Flexor pollicis longus muscles are not commonly involved in the volkmann’s ischaemic contracture. They may get involved later in the severe stage of the condition.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most commonly involved muscle in the Volkmann’s ischaemic contracture is the flexor digitorum profundus, followed by flexor pollicis longus.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 86

choices.text: Complex regional pain syndrome I
Complex regional pain syndrome II

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the clinic after 3 months of traumatic tibial fracture with history of pain and swelling of right leg since 8–10 days. Her skin of that area was shiny, cold and edematous. There was no history of hypertension and diabetes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complex regional pain syndrome Type l (CRPS I)

 

Option A)

 

SUDECK’S OSTEONEURODYSTROPHY/REFLEX SYMPATHETIC  DYSTROPHY/ALGODYSTROPHY/COMPLEX REGIONAL PAIN SYNDROME

 

  • Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) type I is a regional pain syndrome that usually develops after tissue trauma.
  • The symptoms are unrelated to the severity of the initial trauma and are not confined to the distribution of a single peripheral nerve.
  • CRPS type II (causalgia) is a regional pain syndrome that develops after injury to a peripheral nerve, usually a major nerve trunk.
  • Spontaneous pain initially develops within the territory of the affected nerve but eventually may spread outside the nerve distribution.
  • Median > Sciatic (Tibial trunk) are the most common nerves involved.
  • Pain is the primary clinical feature of CRPS.
  • Vasomotor dysfunction, sudomotor abnormalities, or focal edema may occur alone or in combination but must be present for diagnosis.
  • In CRPS, localized sweating (increased resting sweat output) and changes in blood flow may produce temperature differences between affected and unaffected limbs.
  • The most characteristic symptom is pain out of proportion to the inciting event in both severity and duration. It is often burning in character. Hence the term ‘Causalgia' which means burning pain.
  • Swelling is the most consistent physical finding. It often begins in area of injury and is soft initially, as the process continues, oedema gradually becomes firm and involves much broader area.
  • Stiffness and discolouration of skin (red, blue and/or pallor) are other classic signs.
  • Trophic skin changes i.e. skin is shiny, thin with loss of normal wrinkles and creases are characteristically seen late.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Complex regional pain syndrome II. Also known as causalgia, it is a neurological disorder that produces long-lasting, intense, burning pain. It is caused after injury to the peripheral nerves. The most common site of pain is the brachial plexus. It affects the median nerve more commonly, followed by the tibial trunk of the sciatic nerve. There is pins and needles sensation, hypersensitivity, swelling, stiffness, abnormal sweating and skin colour changes.

 

Option C. Fibromyalgia. Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic, widespread musculoskeletal pain. Fatigue, cognitive disturbance, psychiatric and multiple somatic symptoms often accompany the disorder. There is no evidence of tissue inflammation. It has an unknown etiology. The chief complaint of the patient is widespread musculoskeletal pain, which is bilateral and involves both the upper and lower parts of the body. The pain may be localized initially, commonly in the neck and shoulders. The other cardinal symptom is fatigue, especially when waking up from sleep, but it is also in the mid-afternoon. Minor activities may aggravate the pain and fatigue, though inactivity for a prolonged period also increases the symptoms. There is stiffness on waking up in the morning.

 

Option D. Peripheral neuropathy. Symptoms of peripheral neuropathy can range from tingling or numbness to burning pain or paralysis. Other symptoms include muscle weakness, cramps, muscle twitching, loss of muscle and bone, changes in skin, hair, or nails, numbness, loss of balance, loss of pain or sensation, inability to sweat properly, leading to heat intolerance, loss of bladder control, dizziness because of a loss of control over blood pressure etc.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described signs and symptoms and history of the patient are suggestive of presence of complex regional pain syndrome I or sudeck’s osteodystrophy which is caused following trauma.

questions.text: A person of 60 Years of age is suffering from myositis ossificans progressiva. The usual cause of death will be:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lung disease

 

Option C)

 

MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS PROGRESSIVA

 

  • Severe restrictive chest wall disease is the cause of death in myositis ossificans progressive.
  • Limitations of jaw mobility, extremely limited chest expansion, reduced lung volumes (~ 44% of normal) but relatively preserved flow rates and scoliosis/hypokyphosis are other feature.
  • Life expectancy is decreased and premature death usually result from respiratory failure due to restrictive lung disease and their complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nutritional deficiency. In the context of myositis ossificans progressiva (MOP), nutritional deficiency is not typically considered the usual cause of death. MOP is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive heterotopic ossification, i.e., the abnormal formation of bone in muscles, tendons, and ligaments. While nutritional status may impact overall health, it is not directly linked to the progression or outcome of MOP.

 

Option B. Bed sore. Bed sores, also known as pressure ulcers or decubitus ulcers, occur due to prolonged pressure on the skin, often in individuals who are immobile or bedridden. While bed sores can lead to serious complications, including infection and tissue necrosis, they are not typically considered the usual cause of death in individuals with myositis ossificans progressiva. MOP primarily affects the musculoskeletal system and is not directly related to the development of bed sores.

 

Option D. Septicemia. In individuals with myositis ossificans progressiva, infections can occur due to various factors, including compromised mobility, skin breakdown, and immune system dysfunction. Septicemia can result from these infections and is a significant risk for individuals with MOP, especially if the infection spreads rapidly throughout the body.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most usual cause of death in the patient with myositis ossificans progressive will be lung disease in the form of severe restrictive chest wall disease.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 89

choices.text: Occurs due to sudden axial pull on extended elbow
Forearm is held in pronation and flexion
Most commonly occurs between 2–5 years of age
Treatment is quick pronation and flexion of elbow

questions.text: What is not true about pulled elbow?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Treatment is quick pronation and flexion of elbow

 

Option D)

 

PULLED ELBOW/NURSE MAID’S ELBOW

 

  • It is subluxation of radial head or more accurately subluxation of the annular (orbicular) ligament which slips up over the head of radius into the radio-capitellar joint.

 

 

Mechanism of Injury: Traction to elbow.

 

 

  • Clinical Features:
  • Maximum incidence in 1–4 Years age group.
  • The child holds the elbow in slight flexion with the forearm pronated.
  • X-rays are normal
  • Treatment:
  • Reduced by flexing the elbow to 90 degrees and rapidly and firmly rotating the forearm into full supination on outdoor basis without anaesthesia.
  • lmmobilization is not necessary.
  • Supination is a gravity assisted movement and pulled elbow may be reduced spontaneously by gravity, but this may take time.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Occurs due to sudden axial pull on extended elbow. True. Pulled elbow is caused by a sudden axial traction force on the extended elbow that leads to the slip of the annular ligament over the radial head into the radiocapitellar joint.

 

Option B. Forearm is held in pronation and flexion. True. The child on presentation holds the elbow in slight flexion with forearm pronated. The child apprehends any movement of the affected limb.

 

Option C. Most commonly occurs between 2-5 years of age. True. Pulled elbow is commonly seen in children of 1-5 years of age group.

 

Option D. Treatment is quick pronation and flexion of elbow. False. The pulled elbow is reduced by flexing the elbow to 90â° and rapidly but firmly rotating the forearm into full supination. This is done without anaesthesia, and requires no immobilization post reduction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The pulled elbow is seen in children aged 1-5 years following an axial traction to the extended elbow.
  • The child presents with the elbow in slight flexion and the forearm in pronation.
  • It is treated by reduction without anesthesia by elbow flexion to 90â° followed by rapid forearm supination.

choices.text: Anterior pad of fat sign present
Fracture of radius head
Radius head articulation is seen
Supracondylar humerus fracture can raise anterior fat pad

questions.text: X-ray of a 10-year-old child is shown. Which of the following is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fracture of radius head

 

Option B)

 

FAT PAD SIGN

 

  • In children, radial neck fracture is seen.
  • Undisplaced supracondylar fracture humerus can raise the fat pad due to hematoma this is called as fat pad sign.
  • Radiographically, the anterior fat pad is a superimposition of the radial and coronoid fat pads when viewing a lateral radiograph.
  • Their location is anterior to the coronoid and radial fossae located on the distal anterior humerus.
  • These fat pads are slightly more radiolucent than the adjacent muscle tissues, making them visible on a properly positioned 90° lateral radiograph of the elbow.
  • Fat pad sign is known as the “sail sign” due to the triangular sail-like appearance of the anterior fat pad.

 

 

  • The presence of the fat pad sign indicated the presence of elbow joint effusion.
  • The intraarticular, extrasynovial joint effusion elevates the anterior fat pad, indicating an intraarticular fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows the anterior fat pad sign in the elbow.
  • The presence of anterior fat pad sign on radiograph indicates the presence of a radial neck fracture in adults and supracondylar fracture in children.

choices.text: Injury to interosseous membrane
Radial shaft and radio-ulnar joint fracture

questions.text: Essex lopresti lesion in upper limb is
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Injury to interosseous membrane

 

Option A)

 

RADIAL HEAD FRACTURE

 

  • Radial head fractures are common injuries and may occur in association with dislocation of the elbow.
  • A radial head fracture with an associated injury to the interosseous membrane and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint is termed an Essex-Lopresti fracture-dislocation.
  • The injury occurs due to compressive force of trauma transmitted to the forearm through the proximal and distal radioulnar joints and the interosseous membrane.
  • This occurs from a fall or high energy trauma with the elbow extended.
  • This causes wrist pain, displacement at the distal radio-ulnar joint, and/or proximal migration of the radius evident on X-ray.
  • If signs of instability in any plane are present, every attempt should be made to preserve the radial head or perform arthroplasty with a metallic radial head implant.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Essex lopresti lesion in the upper limb is the injury to the interosseous membrane with the radial head fracture and dislocation of the radioulnar joint.

choices.text: It produces instability of elbow joint
It leads to secondary Osteoarthritis of elbow
It causes subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint

questions.text: Excision of head of radius in a child should not be done because:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It causes subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint

 

Option C)

 

RADIAL HEAD EXCISION IN CHILDREN

 

  • Classically, the head of radius should not be excised in children because it will interfere with the synchronous growth of radius and ulna, producing wrist and elbow deformity.
  • It leads to proximal radial migration and subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint.
  • It causes weakness of extremity and discomfort in distal radio-ulnar joint with heavy activities.
  • May produce cubitus valgus deformity and instability.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It produces instability of the elbow joint. The head of the radius plays a crucial role in stabilizing the elbow joint, particularly in certain movements such as rotation of the forearm. Excision of the head of the radius can lead to instability of the elbow joint, impairing its function and potentially causing discomfort or functional limitations. But this can or cannot be seen later in life.

 

Option B. It leads to secondary osteoarthritis of the elbow. The excision of the head of the radius can disrupt the normal biomechanics of the elbow joint, leading to increased stress and wear on the remaining structures. Over time, this can result in secondary osteoarthritis, characterized by the breakdown of cartilage and subsequent pain and stiffness in the joint.

 

Option D. It causes myositis ossificans. Myositis ossificans is not a direct consequence of excision of the head of the radius. Instead, it is a result of trauma or injury.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The excision of the radial head in children is avoided because it most commonly causes the subluxation of the inferior radioulnar joint which may lead to the weakness of the affected limb and may affect the daily activities of the child.

questions.text: If head of the radius is removed, it will result in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valgus deformity

 

Option B)

 

RADIAL HEAD REMOVAL

 

  • Classically, the head of radius should not be excised in children because it will interfere with the synchronous growth of radius and ulna, producing wrist and elbow deformity.
  • It leads to proximal radial migration and subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint.
  • It causes weakness of extremity and discomfort in distal radio-ulnar joint with heavy activities.
  • May produce cubitus valgus deformity and instability.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lengthening of limb. The head of the radius is one of the key structures contributing to the stability and function of the elbow joint. Its removal can lead to alterations in the biomechanics of the joint. However, removing the head of the radius does not directly lead to lengthening of the limb. Limb length is primarily determined by the lengths of the long bones, such as the humerus, radius, and ulna, and alterations in these bones can affect limb length. Removing the head of the radius may cause changes in the mechanics of the elbow joint, but it doesn't directly result in limb lengthening.

 

Option C. Varus deformity. Removal of the head of the radius can disrupt the stability of the elbow joint, leading to changes in alignment. However, it typically results in a valgus deformity rather than a varus deformity.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • If the head of radius is removed in children, it leads to cubitus valgus deformity of the elbow and elbow instability.

questions.text: In a patient with history of trauma and X-ray showing fracture of proximal part of medial bone of forearm with dislocation, the muscle which may get paralysed will be:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor pollicis longus

 

Option C)

 

MONTEGGIA FRACTURE-DISLOCATION

 

  • Posterior interosseous nerve has been most commonly injured nerve in association with Monteggia fracture-dislocation because it takes a turn around radial head and is injured with its dislocation.
  • Among the muscle given in options, Extensor pollicis longus is supplied by posterior interosseous nerve.
  • This causes paralysis of thumb and finger extension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flexor carpi ulnaris. FCU is susceptible to the involvement in the Volkmann’s ischaemic contracture. Since, it is innervated by the ulnar nerve, it is not affected in the monteggia fracture.

 

Option B. Adductor pollicis. This muscle is paralysed in the compression of the deep motor palmar branch of the ulnar nerve. Since the ulnar nerve does not pass through the area of the monteggia fracture, so it is not affected.

 

Option D. Opponens pollicis. This muscle is paralyzed in the median nerve injury. Since the median nerve does not pass through the area of monteggia fracture, so it is not affected.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given description of fracture of proximal part of the medial bone of the forearm with dislocation describes the monteggia fracture-dislocation which is the fracture between the proximal third of the ulna and base of olecranon combined with dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint.
  • In this fracture, the posterior interosseous nerve is damaged which paralyses the extensor pollicis longus muscle, consequently leading to the paralysis of the thumb and finger extension.

choices.text: Monteggia fracture type I

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Monteggia fracture type I

 

Option A)

 

MONTEGGIA FRACTURE-DISLOCATION

 

  • Fractures between the proximal third of the ulna and the base of olecranon combined with dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint.

 

 

  • Direction of dislocation of radial head is used for classification.
  • Bado’s Classification:

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Side swipe fracture. Sideswipe injuries are sustained when a patient while travelling in a vehicle with elbow resting on the window is hit by a coming object or a vehicle on the road.  This leads to a comminuted fracture of the distal humerus.

 

 

Option C. Galeazzi fracture. The Galeazzi fracture is a fracture of the middle to distal one-third of the radius associated with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint. Signs of DRUJ disruption on x-ray are widening of the DRUJ on the PA view, ulnar styloid fracture, displacement of the ulna dorsally on the lateral view, and radial shortening greater than 5 mm.

 

 

Option D. Monteggia fracture type II. Fracture of the proximal or middle third of the ulna with posterior dislocation of the radial head.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The fracture shown in the image is the monteggia type I fracture involving the fracture of the proximal third of the ulna and dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint.

choices.text: Fracture of distal third of radius and dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint
Results from fall on outstretched hand
The distal end of ulna dislocates volarly after disruption of distal radio-ulnar joint
Radius is angulated medially and anteriorly

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The distal end of ulna dislocates volarly after disruption of distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Option C)

 

GALEAZZI FRACTURE-DISLOCATION

 

  • Fracture of the distal third of the radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint is known as galeazzi fracture-dislocation.

 

 

  • There is also damage to interosseous membrane and Triangular Fibro Cartilage complex. 
  • It is called the fracture of necessity.
  • Galeazzi fractures most commonly result from a fall onto an outstretched hand with an extended wrist and hyperpronated forearm.
  • The energy from the radius fracture gets transmitted towards the radioulnar joint leading to dislocation of the DRUJ. 
  • Signs of DRUJ disruption include:
    • Widening of the DRUJ on the PA view
    • Ulnar styloid fracture
    • Displacement of the ulna dorsally on the lateral view
    • Radial shortening greater than 5 mm

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fracture of distal third of radius and dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint. True. Galeazzi fracture-dislocation is the fracture of distal third radius and dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Option B. Results from a fall on outstretched hand. True. This fracture is caused by fall on outstretched hand with extended elbow and hyperpronated forearm.

 

Option C. The distal end of ulna dislocates volarly after disruption of distal radio-ulnar joint. False. The distal end of the ulna dislocates dorsally after the distal radioulnar joint disruption.

 

Option D. Radius is angulated medially and anteriorly. True. Post fracture-dislocation, radius is angulated medially and anteriorly.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the galeazzi fracture-dislocation, the distal end of ulna is dislocated dorsally after the disruption of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

questions.text:
Fracture of necessity includes: 

  1. Cottonâ€™s fracture 
  2. Galeazzi fracture
  3. Monteggia fracture
  4. Rolando fracture
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above 

 

Option D)

 

FRACTURES OF NECESSITY 

 

  • This term is used to describe the fractures that require surgical treatment for optimum results. 
  • Conservative treatment of such fractures do not give good results.
  • Fractures of necessity are:
    • Lateral Condyle fracture of humerus
    • Displaced fracture of olecranon and patella
    • Fracture neck of femur
    • Galeazzi fracture-dislocation
    • Intra-articular fractures
    • Monteggia fracture in adults 
  • Initially, galeazzi fracture is the classical example of fracture of necessity. 
  • Now, other fractures also got included. 
  • Since cottonâ€™s fracture and Rolando fracture are also intra-articular, thus theyâ€™re also the fractures of necessity. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fractures of necessity includes cottonâ€™s fracture, galeazzi fracture, monteggia fracture and Rolando fracture.

questions.text: AP & Lateral Views of wrist x-ray are given. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galeazzi fracture

 

Option A)

 

GALEAZZI FRACTURE

 

  • Fracture of the distal third of the radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint is known as galeazzi fracture-dislocation.

 

 

 

  • There is also damage to interosseous membrane and Triangular Fibro Cartilage complex. 
  • It is called the fracture of necessity.
  • Galeazzi fractures most commonly result from a fall onto an outstretched hand with an extended wrist and hyperpronated forearm.
  • The energy from the radius fracture gets transmitted towards the radioulnar joint leading to dislocation of the DRUJ. 
  • Signs of DRUJ disruption include:
    • Widening of the DRUJ on the PA view
    • Ulnar styloid fracture
    • Displacement of the ulna dorsally on the lateral view
    • Radial shortening greater than 5 mm

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Monteggia fracture. This involves the fracture of the proximal third of the ulna and dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint.

 

 

Option C. Smith fracture. It involves the fracture of the distal radius with associated volar angulation of the distal fracture fragments.

 

 

Option D. Colles fracture. It is the extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment. Severe angulation presents as the dinner fork deformity.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given x-ray views shows the galeazzi fracture of the forearm.

questions.text: Fracture of both bone forearm occurred at same level. Position of the arm in plaster is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mid-prone

 

Option D)

 

FRACTURE BOTH BONE FOREARM TREATMENT

 

  • In children, and sometimes also in adults, it is worth-while first to attempt manipulative reduction under anaesthesia.
  • If this is successful, a full-length arm plaster is applied with elbow at a right angle and the forearm in a position midway between pronation and supination (mid-prone position).
  • Fractures of upper third of radius, therefore, should usually be immobilized with the hand and forearm supinated, so that the distal fragment is rotated into the same axis as the proximal fragment.
  • If the fracture is at, or below, the middle third (distal to pronator teres) of the bone, the proximal fragment has both supinators and pronators muscles attached to it.
  • It therefore takes up the mid position half way between full supination and full pronation, and this forearm fracture should usually be immobilized with the hand and forearm in the mid (neutral) position.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Full supination. For a fracture occurring at the same level in both bones of the forearm, full supination alone may not provide optimal stability or alignment for proper healing. It may also restrict functional movement during the healing process.

 

Option B. 10-degree supination. A slight degree of supination can help maintain alignment of the fractured bones while also allowing some functional movement in the forearm and wrist. But the most preferred position is the mid-prone position of the forearm as it allows a balanced force distribution across the fractured fragments and the soft tissue and offer greater stability.

 

Option C. Full pronation. For a fracture occurring at the same level in both bones of the forearm, full pronation alone may not provide adequate stability or alignment for optimal healing.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Mid-prone position of the forearm in a plaster allows for a more balanced distribution of forces across the fractured bones and surrounding soft tissues.
  • It may offer greater stability and comfort compared to extreme positions of supination or pronation, especially in cases where the fracture involves both bones of the forearm at the same level.

questions.text: All of the following are displacements of Colle’s fracture except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medial displacement

 

Option D)

 

COLLES FRACTURE

 

  • Colle’s fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its cortico-cancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women; as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension.
  • It is one of the most common fractures in elderly.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The displacement seen in the colles fracture are dorsal tilt, impaction or proximal shift, and supination.
  • Medial displacement is not seen in colles fracture instead there is lateral displacement.

choices.text: Volar angulation with Radial deviation occurs
It is an intra articular fracture
It may lead to gunstock deformity due to malunion
It is associated with dorsal angulation

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Colle’s Fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is associated with dorsal angulation

 

Option D)

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Colle’s fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its cortico-cancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women; as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in exten­sion.
  • It is one of the most common fractures in elderly.
  • The Colles fracture is defined as a distal radius fracture with dorsal comminution, dorsal angulation, dorsal displacement, radial shortening, and an associated ulnar styloid fracture.

 

 

  • Complications:
  • Joint Stiffness: Finger stiffness is most common complication.
  • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
  • Sudeck's osteodystrophy/Reflex sympathetic dystrophy.
  • Rupture of extensor pollicis longus tendon.
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome causing median nerve compression.
  • Carpal instability.
  • Triangular-fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) injury and subluxation of inferior radioulnar joint.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Volar angulation with radial deviation occurs. False. In colles fracture, there is a dorsal angulation.

 

Option B. It is an intra-articular fracture. False. Colles' fracture is typically an extra-articular fracture. It occurs just above the wrist joint and does not involve the joint itself.

 

Option C. It may lead to gunstock deformity due to malunion. False. The malunion of the colles fracture is the most common complication, and this leads to dinner fork deformity of the forearm.
 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The colles fracture is an extra-articular fracture which is associated with dorsal angulation of the fracture fragment.
  • Malunion of this fracture leads to dinner fork deformity of the forearm.

questions.text: Modified AlIen’s test is for proper arterial supply at the:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wrist

 

Option C)

 

MODIFIED ALLEN’S TEST

 

  • The Allen test is used to assess collateral blood flow within the hands, specifically testing for the presence of a complete palmar arch.
  • It is performed by first having the patient's arm flexed at the elbow with the fist clenched tightly to exsanguinate the hand.
  • The ulnar and radial arteries are then compressed by the examiner's thumbs simultaneously.
  • The elbow is extended to 180 degrees, avoiding overextension as that could lead to a false-negative test.
  • The fist is subsequently unclenched, and the palm should appear white.
  • The compression is then released from the ulnar artery while maintaining pressure over the radial artery.
  • Once the compression is released, the colour should return to the palm, usually within 10 seconds. 
  • The test is repeated on the same hand while releasing the radial artery first and continuing to compress the ulnar artery if evaluation of radial collateral blood flow is required.
  • If pallor persists within the palm after the patient unclenches their fist and one of the arteries is released, then the test is negative and indicative of an occlusion within the artery that is being released.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Modified Allen’s test is used to assess the arterial supply of the wrist.

questions.text: Dinner fork deformity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colle’s fracture

 

Option A)

 

COLLES FRACTURE COMPLICATIONS

 

  • Joint Stiffness: Finger stiffness is most common complication.
  • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
  • Sudeck's osteodystrophy/Reflex sympathetic dystrophy.
  • Rupture of extensor pollicis longus tendon.
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome causing median nerve compression.
  • Carpal instability.
  • Triangular-fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) injury and subluxation of inferior radioulnar joint.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Smith fracture. It involves a fracture of the distal radius with displacement of the fracture fragment towards the palmar (volar) side of the hand. A Smith fracture typically results in a deformity of "dorsal displacement" or "dorsal tilt”, called garden spade deformity.

 

 

Option C. Chauffeur’s fracture. In a Chauffeur's fracture, the fracture occurs at the base of the radial styloid process. It may lead to deformities such as radial deviation of the thumb due to the attachment of the abductor pollicis longus muscle, which is sometimes referred to as the "Hitchhiker's thumb" or "Gamekeeper's thumb" deformity.

 

 

Option D. Supracondylar fracture humerus. One of the frequent long term complications of supracondylar fracture are angular deformities, of which cubitus varus or “gunstock” deformity.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Dinner fork deformity is seen in the colles fracture as a complication of malunion of the fracture.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 95

choices.text: Palmar deviation and pronation
Dorsal deviation and pronation

questions.text: Position of wrist in cast of Colle’s fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Palmar deviation and pronation

 

Option A)

 

TREATMENT OF COLLES FRACTURE

 

  • Most Colle’s fractures can be successfully treated non-operatively and cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement.
  • That's why position of immobilization in Colle’s fracture is:

 

 

 

 

Reduction of Colle’s fracture

 

  • In younger patients, near-normal function and clinical and radiographic appearance are expected.
  • If maintenance of reduction of Colle’s or Smith fractures requires prolonged immobilization in extreme positions, or reduction is lost early in treatment, closed reduction followed by percutaneous K-wire fixation is done.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In conservative management of the colles fracture, a hand shaking plaster cast is applied.
  • The position of the wrist in this case is that of hand shaking i.e., in forearm pronation, palmar angulation and ulnar deviation of the wrist.

choices.text: Is a severe form of a Colles' fracture
Is often treated by cast

questions.text: Barton’s fracture of the wrist:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Involves radiocarpal subluxation

 

Option A)

 

BARTON’S FRACTURE

 

  • A fracture-dislocation in which the carpus and a rim of distal radius are displaced together.
  • The fracture extends through the dorsal aspect of the articular surface with associated dislocation of the radiocarpal joint.
  • There is no disruption of the radiocarpal ligaments, and the articular surface of the fractured distal radius remains in contact with the proximal carpal row.
  • They usually require open reduction and internal fixation.
  • These fractures are almost impossible to treat by closed means although few advocate an attempt of non-operative management.
  • Plate fixation of volar Barton fractures is carried out.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Is a severe form of Colles’ fracture. ColIe’s fracture is an extra-articular fracture of distal end radius whereas Barton‘s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of distal end radius with carpus dislocation.

 

Option C. Is often treated by cast. Barton’s fracture cannot be treated by closed reduction. It can only be treated with open reduction and internal fixation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Barton’s fracture of the wrist is the radiocarpal subluxation.

questions.text: 1st Carpal bone to ossify is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Capitate

 

Option B)

 

OSSIFICATION OF THE CARPAL BONES

 

  • Ossification of the carpal bones occurs in a predictable sequence, starting with the capitate and ending with the pisiform.
  • At birth, there is no calcification in the carpal bones.
  • Although there is great individual variability, approximate ossification times are as follows:
    • Capitate: 1-3 months
    • Hamate: 2-4 months
    • Triquetrum: 2-3 years
    • Lunate: 2-4 years
    • Scaphoid: 4-6 years
    • Trapezium: 4-6 years
    • Trapezoid: 4-6 years
    • Pisiform: 8-12 years

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Capitate is the first bone to ossify among the carpal bones at the age of 1-3 months.

questions.text: Which Bone does not form the Wrist joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ulna

 

Option D)

 

WRIST JOINT

 

  • Wrist is a radio-carpal joint.
  • Ulna is not a part of wrist joint.
  • Ulna does not directly participate in forming the wrist joint.
  • Instead, it primarily articulates with the radius proximally at the elbow joint and with the bones of the hand distally at the distal radioulnar joint.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Radius. The radius is one of the two forearm bones, and it articulates with the carpal bones of the wrist, specifically with the scaphoid and lunate bones. So, the radius does contribute to forming the wrist joint.

 

Option B. Triquetrum. The triquetrum is one of the carpal bones of the wrist. It articulates with the lunate, pisiform, and hamate bones. Therefore, the triquetrum does participate in forming the wrist joint.

 

Option C. Scaphoid. The scaphoid bone is another carpal bone of the wrist. It is situated on the thumb side of the wrist and articulates with the radius proximally and with other carpal bones distally. The scaphoid indeed contributes to forming the wrist joint.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The wrist joint is formed by an articulation between:
    • Distal end of the radius and the articular disk.
    • Proximal row of the carpal bones (except the pisiform).
  • The ulna does not form the wrist joint.

choices.text: Lower End Radius (Colle’s fracture)

questions.text: Most common bone to get fractured in fall on outstretched hand is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lower End Radius (Colle’s fracture)

 

Option B)

 

COLLES FRACTURE

 

  • The most commonly fractured bone among the given options in case of a fall on an outstretched hand is the lower end radius, whose fracture is known as colles fracture.

 

 

  • This fracture occurs when a person falls onto their outstretched hand with the wrist extended, leading to a characteristic dorsal displacement of the distal fragment of the radius.
  • It is most commonly seen in the osteoporotic elderly females.
  • The fractures commonly seen after a fall on outstretched hand are:
    • Fracture clavicle
    • Surgical neck of humerus fracture
    • Supracondylar fracture humerus and lateral condyle fracture humerus
    • Head and neck fracture of radius
    • Galeazzi fracture dislocation
    • Colle’s fracture (Most common)
    • Radial styloid fracture
    • Fracture scaphoid

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lower end ulna. The lower end of the ulna is not typically the most commonly fractured bone in a fall on an outstretched hand. While fractures of the ulna can occur, they are not as common as fractures involving other bones in this scenario.

 

Option C. 5th metacarpal. Fractures of the 5th metacarpal bone, particularly in the region of the neck, are commonly known as boxer's fractures. These fractures can occur when a person punches an object with a closed fist. While fractures of the metacarpal bones can result from falls, they are not as common in this context compared to fractures of the distal radius.

 

Option D. Capitate. The capitate is one of the carpal bones located in the wrist. Fractures of the capitate bone are less common than fractures involving the distal radius, particularly in a fall on an outstretched hand scenario.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Given the context of a fall on an outstretched hand, Lower End Radius (Colle’s fracture), is the most appropriate answer as it corresponds to the commonly observed injury pattern in such cases.

choices.text: Commonly occurs around the elbow
It matures from inside out
Massage is a known associated factor

questions.text: All of the following are features of myositis ossificans except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It matures from inside out

 

Option B)

 

MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS/HETEROTOPIC OSSIFICATION – HISTORY OF MASSAGE THINK OF IT

 

  • It is heterotopic calcification and ossification in muscle tissue.
  • The name is misnomer as there is no myositis (inflammation of muscle) and rarely ossification in the muscle (because the mineral phase differs from that in bone and no true bone matrix is formed).
  • Myositis is usually seen in 2nd to 3rd decade of life.
  • It is mature from outward to inward direction.
  • Causes:
  1. Injury (trauma) is an important factor when associated with massage.
  2. Myositis Ossificans is seen in Elbow (MC) followed by hip joint.
  3. In elbow, Myositis is seen more commonly anteriorly than posteriorly.
  4. Massage to the elbow and vigorous passive stretching to restore movements is aggravating factor.
  5. It occurs in muscles which are vulnerable to heavy loads, such as brachialis (commonest), biceps.
  6. Surgical trauma, specially, total hip replacement, is precipitating factor.
  • MO not associated with traumatic injury is termed as Pseudomalignant myositis ossificans and it is seen in Neurological disorders, e.g., GB syndrome, AIDS encephalopathy, closed head injury, hypoxic brain injury, Polio, Hemophilia and burns.
  • Pathogenesis: Bone formation in muscle represents metaplasia of fibroblast at the site of injury

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Myositis ossificans is commonly found around the elbow joint, followed by the hip joint.
  • In this condition, the myositis matures from the outside towards the inside.
  • Massage, passive stretching or a trauma (injury or surgery) to the elbow are the most common causes of development of myositis ossificans of the elbow.

choices.text: Life longevity is normal
Most common site involved is the spine

questions.text: False about myositis ossificans progressiva is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Life longevity is normal

 

Option B)

 

MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS PROGRESSIVA CLINICAL FEATURES

 

  • Seen in 1st decade of life.
  • Begins as painful erythematous subfascial nodule mostly located on posterior aspect of neck and back which gradually calcify and eventually ossify (heterotopic ossification).
  • The heterotopic ossification progress in axial to appendicular, cranial to caudal and proximal to distal direction.
  • So the most commonly involved site is neck followed by spine and shoulder girdle and same is the order for limitation of motion.
  • The ossification is irreversible, unlike other forms of heterotopic ossification.
  • Diaphragm, extraocular muscles and smooth muscles are characteristically spared.
  • Primary congenital skeletal abnormality is deformity of great toe.
  • Limitations of jaw mobility, extremely limited chest expansion, reduced lung volumes (~ 44% of normal) but relatively preserved flow rates and scoliosis/hypokyphosis are other feature.
  • Life expectancy is decreased and premature death usually result from respiratory failure due to restrictive lung disease and their complications.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Pneumonia and and other restrictive lung diseases leading to respiratory failure are common and leads to premature death.
  • Life longevity is decreased and there is premature death.
  • The most commonly involved site is the neck followed by the spine and the shoulder.
  • The onset occurs in the 1st decade of the life.

choices.text: Migration of osteoblasts to haematoma
Ossification of subperiosteal haematoma

questions.text: Myositis ossificans is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS PROGRESSIVA

 

  • It is a rare autosomal dominant (AD) disorder of connective tissue differentiation.
  • Main pathogenic mechanism is defective regulation of the induction of endochondral ossification.
  • The proliferating loose myxoid fibrous tissue infiltrates and replaces normally formed fibrous connective tissue and striated muscle.
  • Endochondral ossification is a feature of maturing lesion.
  • Only the absence of normal anatomical orientation differentiates this heterotopic bone from normal.
  • Bone morphogenetic protein 4 is over expressed and Basic fibroblast growth factor which is an extremely potent stimulator of angiogenesis (in vivo) is elevated in urine during acute flare up stage.
  • Clinical Features:
  • Seen in 1st decade of life.
  • Begins as painful erythematous subfascial nodule mostly located on posterior aspect of neck and back which gradually calcify and eventually ossify (heterotopic ossification).
  • The heterotopic ossification progress in axial to appendicular, cranial to caudal and proximal to distal direction. So the most commonly involved site is neck followed by spine and shoulder girdle and same is the order for limitation of motion.
  • The ossification is irreversible, unlike other forms of heterotopic ossification.
  • Diaphragm, extraocular muscles and smooth muscles are characteristically spared.
  • Primary congenital skeletal abnormality is deformity of great toe.
  • Limitations of jaw mobility, extremely limited chest expansion, reduced lung volumes (~ 44% of normal) but relatively preserved flow rates and scoliosis/hypokyphosis are another features.
  • Life expectancy is decreased and premature death usually result from respiratory failure due to restrictive lung disease and their complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Migration of osteoblasts to haematoma. Osteoblasts cells are responsible for bone formation. When there's trauma or injury to a muscle, there might be bleeding leading to the formation of a hematoma. In myositis ossificans, it is believed that osteoblasts from nearby bone or from the muscle itself migrate to the hematoma and contribute to the formation of new bone.

 

Option B. New bone formation. This is a characteristic feature of myositis ossificans.

 

Option C. Ossification of subperiosteal haematoma. In myositis ossificans, it is possible for the hematoma to undergo ossification, leading to the formation of bone in the muscle tissue.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Myositis ossificans occurs due to the 1) migration of the osteoblast cells to the haematoma, 2) new bone formation (characteristic feature), and 3) ossification of the subperiosteal haematoma.

questions.text: Most common complication of Colles fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Finger stiffness

 

Option C)

 

COMPLICATIONS OF COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Joint Stiffness: Finger stiffness is most common complication. Wrist, elbow, and shoulder are other joints to become stiff.
  • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.

 

 

 

  • Sudeck's osteodystrophy/Reflex sympathetic dystrophy - Colle’s fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
  • Rupture of extensor pollicis longus tendon.

 

 

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome causing median nerve compression.
  • Carpal instability.
  • Triangular-fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) injury and subluxation of inferior radioulnar joint.
  • Delayed union and non-union are extremely rare.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Malunion. This is the second most common complication of colles fracture after finger stiffness.

 

Option B. Avascular necrosis. This is not a possible complication of colles fracture. Instead, it is seen after the scaphoid fracture.

 

Option D. Rupture of EPL tendon. It is a complication of colles fracture but not commonly seen.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Finger stiffness is the most common complication of colles fracture followed by malunion, leading to dinner fork deformity.

choices.text: Occurs in old age
Occurs at cortico-cancellous junction
Garden spade deformity is seen

questions.text: All are true about colles fracture except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Garden spade deformity is seen

 

Option D)

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Colle’s fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its cortico-cancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women; as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in exten­sion.
  • It is one of the most common fractures in elderly.
  • The Colles fracture is defined as a distal radius fracture with dorsal comminution, dorsal angulation, dorsal displacement, radial shortening, and an associated ulnar styloid fracture.

 

 

  • Complications:
  • Joint Stiffness: Finger stiffness is most common complication.
  • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
  • Sudeck's osteodystrophy/Reflex sympathetic dystrophy.
  • Rupture of extensor pollicis longus tendon.
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome causing median nerve compression.
  • Carpal instability.
  • Triangular-fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) injury and subluxation of inferior radioulnar joint.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The colles fracture occurs at the cortico-cancellous junction of the lower end of the radius.
  • It is most commonly seen in the osteoporotic elderly females.
  • The fracture fragments are supinated, laterally displaced, and dorsally shifted.
  • The most commonly seen deformity is the dinner fork deformity, mostly after the malunion of the fracture.

choices.text: Trans scaphoid-perilunate disruption fracture
Hook of hamate fracture

questions.text: A young man had a fall on his outstretched hand, presented to the hospital with pain on the radial side of wrist and swelling in the anatomical snuff box. X-ray showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scaphoid fracture

 

Option A)

 

CARPAL INJURIES

 

  • Relative Incidence of Carpal Bone Fractures: Scaphoid > Triquetral >Trapezium
  • Fracture Scaphoid:
    • Tenderness in anatomical snuff box!
    • Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children.
    • Scaphoid fracture is seen most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30.
    • Middle third (Waist) fractures are most common accounting for 70% of scaphoid fractures > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%), in adults and adolescents.
    • Distal pole avulsion type fracture is most common fracture type in children.
    • These injuries can be misdiagnosed initially as a simple wrist sprain.  
    • Patients present with wrist pain following a fall onto an outstretched hand.
    • Axial loading of the wrist in forced hyperextension and radial deviation can cause the fracture.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Trans scaphoid-perilunate disruption fracture. It is caused by high-energy trauma and result from an axial load applied to the outstretched hand. Load application to the fixed pronated forearm leads to hyperextension, intercarpal supination, and ulnar deviation of the wrist. There is pain and swelling over the hand and wrist, and gross deformity of the wrist can be noted. Evidence of median nerve injury is common. Acute carpal tunnel syndrome is observed. The key to diagnosis is recognizing the dislocated head of the capitate to the lunate in a radiograph.

 

 

Option C. Hook of hamate fracture. Hook of hamate fractures are rare, often missed, injuries generally as a result of a direct blow to the hamate bone, most commonly seen in athletes. Symptoms include ulnar-sided wrist pain, hypothenar pain and pain with activities requiring tight grip. PA view shows absence of eye sign or cortical ring which is normally produced by an intact hook.

 

 

Option D. Distal radius fracture. These fractures most frequently occur as a result of fall on the outstretched hand (FOOSH) injuries. In the elderly, they are often the result of low-energy falls from a standing or seated position. They are often comminuted and intra-articular fractures. Patients with distal radial fractures will often complain of post-traumatic distal upper extremity pain.
 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image, clinical findings and the history of the patient are suggestive of scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: Axis of upper limb passes through:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capitulum

 

Option A)

 

AXIS OF UPPER LIMB

 

  • The mechanical axis of the upper limb passes through the centre of the humeral head, the centre of the capitate eminence of the humerus, the centre of the head of the radius, and the centre of the ulnar head.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The axis of the upper limb passes through the capitulum.

choices.text: It is the most commonly fractured carpal bone
Persistent tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox is highly suggestive of fracture
Immediate X-ray of hand may not reveal fracture line

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is not correct regarding fracture of the scaphoid?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Malunion is a frequent complication

 

Option D)

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children.
  • Scaphoid fracture is seen most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30.
  • A delay in diagnosis and treatment of this fracture may alter the prognosis for union.
  • A wrist sprain that is sufficiently severe to require radiographic examination initially should be treated as a possible fracture of the scaphoid, and radiographs should be repeated in 2 weeks even though initial radiographs may be negative.
  • Fullness and tenderness in anatomical snuff box.
  • Proximal pressure along the axis of the thumb may be painful.
  • Recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.
  • MRI can diagnose occult fractures.
  • The problem of union in scaphoid fracture are delayed union or non-union (not malunion).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured bone among the carpal bones.
  • The presence of fullness and persistent tenderness in the anatomical snuff box is suggestive of a scaphoid fracture.
  • Immediate x-ray of the hand does not reveal the fracture.
  • Recent fracture can be seen in the oblique view of the x-ray or on the MRI.
  • The most frequent complication of this fracture is either delayed union or non-union.

questions.text: In children, fracture scaphoid is though rare but usually involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Distal pole

 

Option D)

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE IN CHILDREN

 

  • Although uncommon, fractures of the scaphoid in children tend to be avulsions of the distal pole accounting for 75%, with 20% of the waist and 5% of the proximal pole.
  • Distal pole avulsion type fracture is most common fracture type in children.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The part of the scaphoid bone most commonly fractured in children is the distal pole of the scaphoid followed by the waist and the proximal pole (least commonly fractured).

questions.text: Most common site of scaphoid fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Waist

 

Option A)

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Middle third (Waist) fractures are most common accounting for 70% of scaphoid fractures > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%), in adults and adolescents.
  • Distal pole avulsion type fracture is most common fracture type in children.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common site of scaphoid fracture is the waist or middle 1/3rd followed by proximal pole and the distal pole.

questions.text: In non-union of scaphoid, vascularized muscle-pedicle graft is taken from:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pronator quadratus

 

Option C)

 

NON-UNION SCAPHOID FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Scaphoid fractures frequently present with nonunion and proximal pole necrosis, the treatment of which is bone grafting.
  • Pronator quadratus pedicled vascularized bone graft is an attractive option for managing scaphoid nonunion.
  • Lying adjacent to the fracture site, bone can be harvested and transferred without making any other incisions.
  • This procedure introduces another source of blood supply to the fracture site and hence improves fracture healing.
  • It is an easy and robust flap, with a short learning curve, not requiring microvascular expertise.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pronator teres. It originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus and inserts onto the radius bone. While pronator teres has a vascularized blood supply, it is not commonly used for vascularized muscle-pedicle grafts in the treatment of non-union of the scaphoid bone.

 

Option B. Brachioradialis. It originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus and inserts onto the radius. Brachioradialis has a vascularized blood supply and can potentially be used as a source of vascularized muscle-pedicle graft in the treatment of non-union of the scaphoid bone.

 

Option D. Extensor pollicis longus. It originates from the middle third of the ulna and inserts onto the distal phalanx of the thumb. While extensor pollicis longus has a vascularized blood supply, it is not commonly used for vascularized muscle-pedicle grafts in the treatment of non-union of the scaphoid bone.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Out of the given options, the most feasible vascularized muscle-pedicle graft for the treatment of the non-union of scaphoid fracture is the pronator quadratus due to its close location and good vascularization.

choices.text: Lunate and carpal bones dislocate anteriorly
Lunate stays in place and carpal bones dislocate
Lunate and carpal bones dislocate posteriorly
Lunate dislocates anteriorly, but carpal bones stay in place

questions.text: Perilunate dislocation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lunate stays in place and carpal bones dislocate

 

Option B)

 

PERILUNATE DISLOCATION

 

  • The lunate remains in position and the rest of the carpals dislocate dorsally.
  • Perilunate dislocation is more common.
  • Complications may be AVN, osteoarthritis and median nerve injury.
  • The most common type of perilunate instability is trans-scaphoid perilunate fracture dislocation.
  • Median nerve is most commonly involved nerve.
  • The most commonly used method of closed reduction is Tavernier’s maneuver.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In perilunate dislocation, the lunate bone stays at its place and all other carpal bones dislocate dorsally.

questions.text: A patient presents with wrist trauma. On investigations, patient is diagnosed to have a sprained wrist without any evidence of fracture. There is tenderness in anatomical snuffbox. Which ligament is commonly involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scapholunate ligament

 

Option A)

 

SCAPHOLUNATE LIGAMENT INJURY

 

  • Scapholunate interosseous ligament is a C-shaped structure connecting the dorsal, proximal and volar surfaces of the scaphoid and lunate bones.
  • The dorsal component provides the greatest constraint to translation between the scaphoid and lunate bones.
  • Scapholunate ligament is commonly injured at wrist.
  • Scapholunate Ligament Injury is a source of dorsoradial wrist pain with chronic injuries leading to wrist instability.
  • It occurs in approximately 10-30% of intra-articular distal radius fractures or carpal fractures.
  • Mechanism of injury is sudden impact force applied to the hand and wrist causing scapholunate dissociation.
  • Injury occurs most commonly with wrist positioned in extension, ulnar deviation and carpal supination.
  • Symptoms include dorsal and radial-sided wrist pain, pain increased with loading across the wrist (e.g. push up position), clicking or catching in the wrist, and may be associated with wrist instability or weakness.
  • On examination, there may be swelling over the dorsal aspect of the wrist, tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox or over the dorsal scapholunate interval, and pain is increased with extreme wrist extension and radial deviation.
  • Scapholunate dissociation causes the scaphoid to flex palmarly and the lunate to dorsiflex.
  • Scapholunate dissociation has Terry Thomas Sign i.e., the scapholunate gap is > 3mm with clenched fist view.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Radial collateral ligament. Radial collateral ligament injuries of the thumb metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, associated with partial or complete tear of the ligament, are uncommon injuries of the thumb. Acute collateral ligament injuries may be seen during sporting activities. Mechanism of injury is radially-directed force causing hyper-abduction moment at the thumb MCP. Radial-sided MCP pain is the most common complaint for RCL tear. Tenderness is present at site of ligament injury (proximal for RCL).

 

Option C. Lunotriquetral ligament. Lunotriquetral Ligament Injuries are rare traumatic injuries to the wrist that can lead to volar intercalated segment instability (VISI) which is caused by a combination of injury to the lunotriquetral ligament and the dorsal radiocarpal ligament. It is less common than Scapholunate ligament injury. This injury occurs with wrist hyperextension or extension and radial deviation. The patient experiences ulnar sided pain that is worse with pronation and ulnar deviation (power grip).

 

Option D. Ulnar collateral ligament. Ulnar collateral ligament injury of the thumb, also known as skier's thumb or gamekeeper's thumb, is an injury of the ulnar collateral ligament of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. Injuries are often sustained by activities or traumatic events that force the thumb into extreme abduction or hyperextension. The patient complains of discomfort localized to the first metacarpophalangeal joint area. There may be accompanying swelling near or at the thumb base. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given clinical presentation of the patient of history of traumatic wrist sprain and tenderness in anatomical snuff box are suggestive of scapholunate ligament injury.

choices.text: Extra-articular fracture of the 1st metacarpal
Intra-articular fracture of the 1st metacarpal

questions.text: Bennett's fracture is an:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intra-articular fracture of the 1st metacarpal

 

Option C)

 

BENNETT’S FRACTURE

 

  • Bennett’s fracture is an intra articular fracture through the base of the first metacarpal in which the shaft is laterally dislocated by the unopposed pull of the abductor pollicis longus.
  • The medial projection of the thumb metacarpal base on which the volar oblique ligament attaches remains in place.
  • It is common fracture among the boxers.
  • The technique of closed pinning described by Wagner is preferred, but if reduction is unsatisfactory, open reduction is indicated.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Bennett’s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the 1st metacarpal bone i.e., the base of the thumb.

questions.text: Boxer’s fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5th metacarpal fracture

 

Option C)

 

BOXER’S FRACTURE

 

  • A Boxer’s fracture is a fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck, named for the classic mechanism of injury in which direct trauma is applied to a clenched fist. 
  • This represents 10% of all hand fractures.
  • The most common mechanism of injury for Boxer’s fracture is punching, e.g., the axial pressure applied to the metacarpal bone when the fist is in a clenched position.
  • Direct trauma to the dorsum of the hand may also cause a fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck.
  • Unlike many other hand and wrist fractures, a Boxer’s fracture typically does not occur with a fall onto an outstretched hand.  
  • Males aged 10 to 19 have the highest incidence, followed by males aged 20 to 29.
  • Patients with Boxer’s fractures present with complaints of dorsal hand pain, swelling, and possible deformity.
  • Boxer’s fractures are typically associated with apex dorsal angulation, thereby resulting in depression of the MCP joint and loss of the normal knuckle contour.
  • With significantly angulated fractures, “pseudo-clawing” may be observed due to damage to the extensor apparatus; pseudo-clawing is a hyperextension of the MCP joint and flexion at the PIP joint.
  • Normal angulation of the metacarpal head to the neck is 15 degrees, so the angulation of the fracture should be measured as that more than the baseline of 15 degrees.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Radial styloid fracture. This is called Chauffer’s fracture. These are the intra-articular fractures of the radial styloid process, sustained either from direct trauma to the back of the wrist or from forced dorsiflexion and abduction.

 

 

Option B. Reverse colle’s fracture. This is called Smith’s fracture which is the fracture of the distal radius with volar displacement or angulation, resulting from fall on the dorsum of the hand with a flexed wrist.

 

 

Option D. 1st metacarpal fracture. It is called the Bennett’s fracture which is an intra-articular fracture of the base of 1st metacarpal where the shaft dislocates laterally by the pull of the abductor pollicis longus muscle.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Boxer’s fracture is the fracture of the 5th metacarpal bone, commonly seen in boxers.

choices.text: Rupture of flexor pollicis longus tendon

questions.text: All of the following can be the complications of a malunited Colle’s fracture except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rupture of flexor pollicis longus tendon

 

Option A)

 

COMPLICATIONS OF COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Joint Stiffness: Finger stiffness is most common complication. Wrist, elbow, and shoulder are other joints to become stiff.
  • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.

 

 

  • Sudeck's osteodystrophy/Reflex sympathetic dystrophy - Colle’s fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
  • Rupture of extensor pollicis longus tendon.

 

 

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome causing median nerve compression.
  • Carpal instability.
  • Triangular-fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) injury and subluxation of inferior radioulnar joint.
  • Delayed union and non-union are extremely rare.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Out of the given options, rupture of the flexor pollicis longus tendon is not a complication of colles fracture.
  • Instead, rupture of the extensor pollicis longus tendon is a complication.
  • Other complications include reflex sympathetic dystrophy, carpal tunnel syndrome, carpal instability etc.

questions.text: Sudeck’s dystrophy symptoms are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased bone density

 

Option B)

 

SYMPTOMS OF SUDECK’S DYSTROPHY

 

  • Spontaneous pain initially develops within the territory of the affected nerve but eventually may spread outside the nerve distribution.
  • Median > Sciatic (Tibial trunk) are the most common nerves involved.
  • Pain is the primary clinical feature of CRPS.
  • Vasomotor dysfunction, sudomotor abnormalities, or focal edema may occur alone or in combination but must be present for diagnosis.
  • In CRPS, localized sweating (increased resting sweat output) and changes in blood flow may produce temperature differences between affected and unaffected limbs.
  • The most characteristic symptom is pain out of proportion to the inciting event in both severity and duration. It is often burning in character. Hence the term ‘Causalgia' which means burning pain.
  • Swelling is the most consistent physical finding. It often begins in area of injury and is soft initially, as the process continues, oedema gradually becomes firm and involves much broader area.
  • Stiffness and discolouration of skin (red, blue and/or pallor) are other classic signs.
  • Trophic skin changes i.e. skin is shiny, thin with loss of normal wrinkles and creases are characteristically seen late.
  • The most common radiographic finding is localized osteopenia – increased blood flow to the bone.

 

 

Patchy osteopenia

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly seen symptoms of sudeck’s dystrophy are pain, sweating and stiffness.
  • It does not present with increased bone density. Instead, there is osteopenia or decreased bone density in the local affected area, evident on the radiograph.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 96

choices.text: Erythematous and cyanotic discolouration

questions.text: Regarding Sudeck’s osteodystrophy, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Self-limiting and good prognosis

 

Option D)

 

SUDECK’S OSTEODYSTROPHY

 

  • Symptoms:
    • Spontaneous pain initially develops within the territory of the affected nerve but eventually may spread outside the nerve distribution.
    • Median > Sciatic (Tibial trunk) are the most common nerves involved.
    • Pain is the primary clinical feature of CRPS.
    • Vasomotor dysfunction, sudomotor abnormalities, or focal edema may occur alone or in combination but must be present for diagnosis.
    • In CRPS, localized sweating (increased resting sweat output) and changes in blood flow may produce temperature differences between affected and unaffected limbs.
    • The most characteristic symptom is pain out of proportion to the inciting event in both severity and duration. It is often burning in character. Hence the term ‘Causalgia' which means burning pain.
    • Swelling is the most consistent physical finding. It often begins in area of injury and is soft initially, as the process continues, oedema gradually becomes firm and involves much broader area.
    • Stiffness and discolouration of skin (red, blue and/or pallor) are other classic signs.
    • Trophic skin changes i.e. skin is shiny, thin with loss of normal wrinkles and creases are characteristically seen late.
    • The most common radiographic finding is localized osteopenia – increased blood flow to the bone.
  • Prognosis:
    • Recovery is prolonged and painful both for patient and surgeon.
    • 3 years usually elapse before the bones are remineralized and it is rare that full range of movements returns.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The sudeck’s dystrophy is characterised by burning pain, stiffness, swelling and discolouration of the skin (erythematous, cyanotic, pallor).
  • The prognosis is usually prolonged and painful.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 97

questions.text: Garden spade deformity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Smith’s fracture

 

Option C)

 

SMITH’S FRACTURE

 

  • It is a distal radius fracture with volar displacement or angulation of the distal fragment.
  • This condition is also known as a reverse Colles fracture.
  • A Smith fracture produces an "inverse dinner fork deformity" or “garden spade deformity”.

 

 

  • Smith fractures commonly occur either as a fall onto a flexed wrist or as a direct blow to the dorsal aspect of the wrist.
  • The physical exam may reveal a warm, tender distal forearm deformity, with edema visible on the volar side and the ulna protruding on the wrist dorsum.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Barton’s fracture. Barton's fracture is a type of distal radius fracture where the fracture line extends into the wrist joint. This fracture typically involves displacement of the fractured fragment, which can lead to significant deformity. Barton's fractures are more commonly characterized by volar or dorsal displacement of the distal fragment of the radius, rather than resembling the shape of a garden spade.

 

Option B. Colles fracture. This involves the fracture of the lower end of radius at its cortico-cancellous junction. It may present as a dinner fork deformity if the fracture is malunited.

 

Option D. Bennet’s fracture. Bennett's fracture involves the base of the first metacarpal bone, near the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb. This fracture is an intra-articular fracture. It can lead to deformity and instability of the thumb, and is often characterized by subluxation or dislocation of the first metacarpal base, leading to a loss of thumb function and stability.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Garden spade deformity is seen in the Smith’s fracture.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 98

choices.text: Open reduction and fixation
Plaster cast with forearm in pronation
Closed reduction with below-elbow cast
Above-elbow cast with forearm in supination

questions.text: Management of Smith’s fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Above-elbow cast with forearm in supination
