Option D)

 

SMITH FRACTURE MANAGEMENT

 

  • Treatment is closed reduction and immobilization in a long arm (above elbow) cast with forearm in supination and wrist in extension.
  • Percutaneous pinning may be done in unstable fractures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Open reduction and fixation. Surgery may be considered when conservative management is not enough to reduce a Smith fracture. The choice of surgical approach depends on the injury's extent, degree of displacement, patient's age, occupation, and overall health. The first option is closed reduction with percutaneous pinning (CRPP). The second option is external fixation. The third option is ORIF.

 

Option B. Plaster cast with forearm in pronation. The cast applied in a long arm/above elbow cast with the forearm kept in supination and not pronation.

 

Option C. Closed reduction with below-elbow cast. The cast applied for closed reduction is above elbow and not below elbow.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The preferred management of smith’s fracture is the closed reduction and immobilization in an above elbow cast with forearm in supination and wrist in extension.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 98

choices.text: Fracture distal end humerus
Extra-articular fracture distal end radius
Intra-articular fracture distal end radius
Intra-articular fracture distal end radius with carpal bone subluxation

questions.text: Barton’s fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intra-articular fracture distal end radius with carpal bone subluxation

 

Option D)

 

BARTON’S FRACTURE

 

  • A fracture-dislocation in which the carpus and a rim of distal radius are displaced together.
  • The fracture extends through the dorsal aspect of the articular surface with associated dislocation of the radiocarpal joint.
  • There is no disruption of the radiocarpal ligaments, and the articular surface of the fractured distal radius remains in contact with the proximal carpal row.
  • They usually require open reduction and internal fixation.
  • These fractures are almost impossible to treat by closed means although few advocate an attempt of non-operative management.
  • Plate fixation of volar Barton fractures is carried out.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Barton’s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the radius with carpal bone subluxation.

questions.text: Scaphoid fracture which area has maximum chances of Avascular Necrosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proximal 1/3rd

 

Option A)

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Middle third (Waist) fractures are most common accounting for 70% of scaphoid fractures > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%), in adults and adolescents.
  • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally.

 

 

Scaphoid blood supply

 

  • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The part of the scaphoid that has maximum chances of development of avascular necrosis after scaphoid fracture is the proximal 1/3rd part > middle 1/3rd > distal 1/3rd.

questions.text: Rolando Fracture involves base of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st metacarpal

 

Option A)

 

ROLANDO FRACTURE

 

  • Comminuted fracture of First Metacarpal Base.
  • In 1910, Rolando described a T or Y-shaped intra-articular fracture involving the base of 1st metacarpal that usually does not result in diaphyseal displacement as in a Bennet' fracture.

 

 

 

  • Because of the likelihood of post-traumatic arthritis after these fractures, accurate reduction is important.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Rolando fracture is a 3-part, T- or Y-shaped, comminuted, intra-articular fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal.

choices.text: Examine the child under GA
Elevate the limb and observe

questions.text: A one-and-a-half-year-old child holding her father’s hand slipped and fell but did not let go of her father’s hand. After that, she continued to cry and hold the forearm in pronated position and refused to move the affected extremity. Which of the following management at this stage is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supinate the forearm

 

Option A)

 

PULLED ELBOW

 

  • This is a case of pulled elbow.
  • It is caused by the traction pull to the elbow that subluxates the radial head at the elbow.
  • Treatment is simple. The child's attention is diverted, the elbow is quickly supinated and then slightly flexed.
  • The treatment does not require anesthesia or immobilization post reduction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given case history describes the diagnosis of pulled elbow in the child.
  • It is treated on the outdoor basis without anesthesia reducing the elbow.
  • For reduction, the elbow is flexed followed by rapid and firm supination of the forearm.

choices.text: Osteoarthritis of first CMC joint

questions.text: Stellate ganglion block is useful in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sudeck’s osteodystrophy

 

Option A)

 

SUDECK’S OSTEODYSTROPHY TREATMENT

 

  • Stellate ganglion blockade is a commonly used invasive therapeutic technique that often provides temporary pain relief, but the efficacy of repetitive blocks is uncertain.
  • Stellate ganglion block (SGB) is the blockade of the sympathetic ganglia in the lower cervical and upper thoracic region.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Compound palmar ganglion. Compound palmar ganglion, also known as chronic flexor tenosynovitis, is a condition involving the flexor tendons around the wrist, above and below the flexor retinaculum. Most common etiologies are tuberculosis and rheumatoid arthritis. Treatment of choice for such conditions include complete excision of the mass along with the radical synovectomy of the wrist joint and associated flexor tendon sheaths followed by anti-tubercular medications. With early diagnosis and treatment good recovery can be achieved. 

 

Option C. Tenosynovitis. Infectious tenosynovitis treatment can include broad-spectrum antibiotics such as vancomycin at 15 to 20 mg/kg/dose every 8 to 12 hours with a third-generation cephalosporin at 1 to 2 g IV every 24 hours. Non-infectious tenosynovitis is treated conservatively with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as naproxen. Additional first-line treatment may consist of activity modification, splinting, and glucocorticoid injections. Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) such as glucocorticoids may be additionally helpful in patients in patients who fail a trial of NSAIDs. Surgical intervention may become necessary after 3 to 6 months of progression despite conservative therapy. Surgical intervention may involve the decompression of affected tendons as well as debridement of inflammatory tissues.

 

Option D. Osteoarthritis of first CMC joint. Activity modification, or using splints, slings, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and cortisol injections are all examples of conservative treatment. Surgical options include osteotomy, trapezial excision, ligament reconstruction with or without tendon interposition, and various prosthetic interpositional implants with or without trapezial excision. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Stellate ganglion blockade is used for the temporary pain management in the sudeck’s osteodystrophy.

 

Ref: OPQR, 6th edition, page no. 97
